answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment for up to 7 years, along with a fine and forfeiture of any property used in or acquired by such depredation.

paragraphs.context: 155. Whoever receives any property knowing the same to have been taken in the commission of any of the offences mentioned in sections 153 and 154, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine and to forfeiture of the property so received.

qas.question: What is the punishment for receiving property taken by war or depredation under Sections 153 and 154 under Section 155?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment for up to 7 years, along with a fine and forfeiture of the property received.

paragraphs.context: 156. Whoever, being a public servant and having the custody of any State prisoner or prisoner of war, voluntarily allows such prisoner to escape from any place in which such prisoner is confined, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for a public servant who allows a State prisoner or prisoner of war to escape voluntarily under Section 156?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment for life or up to 10 years, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: 157. Whoever, being a public servant and having the custody of any State prisoner or prisoner of war, negligently suffers such prisoner to escape from any place of confinement in which such prisoner is confined, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for a public servant negligently allowing a prisoner of war or State prisoner to escape under Section 157?

answers.text: The punishment is simple imprisonment for up to 3 years, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: 158. Whoever knowingly aids or assists any State prisoner or prisoner of war in escaping from lawful custody, or rescues or attempts to rescue any such prisoner, or harbours or conceals any such prisoner who has escaped from lawful custody, or offers or attempts to offer any resistance to the recapture of such prisoner, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine. Explanation.—A State prisoner or prisoner of war, who is permitted to be at large on his parole within certain limits in India, is said to escape from lawful custody if he goes beyond the limits within which he is allowed to be at large.

qas.question: What is the punishment for aiding or assisting a State prisoner or prisoner of war in escaping under Section 158?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment for life or up to 10 years, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: 159. Whoever abets the committing of mutiny by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India or attempts to seduce any such officer, soldier, sailor or airman from his allegiance or his duty, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for abetting mutiny or attempting to seduce an officer, soldier, sailor, or airman from their duty under Section 159?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment for life or up to 10 years, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: 160. Whoever abets the committing of mutiny by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India, shall, if mutiny be committed in consequence of that abetment, be punished with death or with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for abetting mutiny, if mutiny is committed as a result under Section 160?

answers.text: The punishment is death or imprisonment for life, or imprisonment for up to 10 years, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: 161. Whoever abets an assault by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India, on any superior officer being in the execution of his office, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for abetting an assault on a superior officer in the Army, Navy, or Air Force under Section 161?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment for up to 3 years, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: Section 335 further elaborates on the offense of making false documents or electronic records. A person commits forgery in the following ways: A. Dishonest Creation or Execution of False Documents. A person who dishonestly or fraudulently makes, signs, seals, or executes a document or an electronic record with the intent to deceive another person into believing it to be genuine when it is not. This includes: Making or transmitting any part of a document or electronic record. Affixing an electronic signature to a document without lawful authority. Creating a mark that suggests authenticity or execution of the document.

qas.question: What actions constitute dishonest creation or execution of false documents or electronic records?

answers.text: Making, signing, sealing, or executing a document or electronic record with the intent to deceive, including affixing an electronic signature without lawful authority or creating a mark suggesting authenticity.

paragraphs.context: B. Altering a Document or Electronic Record Without Authority. Dishonestly or fraudulently altering a document or electronic record: This could be through cancellation or any other method of altering the content of the document, after it has been made, signed, or affixed with an electronic signature. The alteration can be made either by the same person who originally executed it or by another person, even if that person is alive or deceased at the time of alteration.

qas.question: What actions are considered altering a document or electronic record without authority?

answers.text: Dishonestly or fraudulently altering a document or electronic record, such as cancellation or changing its content after it has been signed or affixed with an electronic signature.

paragraphs.context: C. Inducing a Person to Alter or Sign a Document Fraudulently. A person who dishonestly or fraudulently induces someone else to: Sign, seal, execute, or alter a document or electronic record, Affix an electronic signature, knowing that the person: Cannot comprehend the document or its alteration due to unsoundness of mind or intoxication, Is deceived, and does not know the contents of the document or the nature of the alteration.

qas.question: What constitutes inducing someone to alter or sign a document fraudulently?

answers.text: Dishonestly or fraudulently inducing someone to sign, seal, execute, or alter a document, or affix an electronic signature, knowing the person cannot comprehend the document due to unsoundness of mind or intoxication, or is deceived.

paragraphs.context: Illustrations of Forgery: Example (a): A has a letter of credit for ₹10,000 written by Z. A adds extra digits to make the amount ₹1,00,000, intending to deceive B into believing Z wrote the original amount. A has committed forgery.

qas.question: What is the forgery committed in Example (a)?

answers.text: A adds extra digits to a letter of credit, changing ₹10,000 to ₹1,00,000, intending to deceive B.

paragraphs.context: Example (b): A, without Z’s authority, affixes Z’s seal to a conveyance document purporting to transfer an estate to A. A intends to sell the estate to B and defraud B of the purchase money. A has committed forgery.

qas.question: What is the forgery committed in Example (b)?

answers.text: A affixes Z’s seal to a conveyance document without authority, intending to sell the estate to B and defraud B.

paragraphs.context: Example (c): A picks up a cheque signed by B, payable to bearer, but with no sum inserted. A fraudulently fills in the amount of ₹10,000. A has committed forgery.

qas.question: What is the forgery committed in Example (c)?

answers.text: A fills in the amount ₹10,000 on a cheque signed by B, without authorization.

paragraphs.context: Example (d): A gives B a cheque with A’s signature but without the sum inserted, authorizing B to fill in the amount not exceeding ₹10,000. However, B fraudulently fills in ₹20,000. B has committed forgery.

qas.question: What is the forgery committed in Example (d)?

answers.text: B fraudulently fills in ₹20,000 instead of the authorized ₹10,000 on a cheque.

paragraphs.context: Example (e): A draws a bill of exchange in B's name without B’s authority, intending to deceive a banker into discounting the bill. A is guilty of forgery.

qas.question: What is the forgery committed in Example (e)?

answers.text: A draws a bill of exchange in B's name without authority, intending to deceive a banker.

paragraphs.context: Example (f): A alters Z’s will, scratching out B’s name, intending to deceive others into believing that the estate was left solely to A and C. A has committed forgery.

qas.question: What is the forgery committed in Example (f)?

answers.text: A alters Z’s will by scratching out B’s name, intending to deceive others.

paragraphs.context: Example (g): B fraudulently erases the words “Pay to Z or his order” from a Government promissory note, changing it to a blank endorsement. B has committed forgery.

qas.question: What is the forgery committed in Example (g)?

answers.text: B erases the words 'Pay to Z or his order' from a Government promissory note, changing it to a blank endorsement.

paragraphs.context: Example (h): A sells an estate to Z and later executes a second conveyance to B with a backdated document, intending to deceive Z into believing B received the estate before Z. A has committed forgery.

qas.question: What is the forgery committed in Example (h)?

answers.text: A executes a backdated conveyance to B, intending to deceive Z.

paragraphs.context: Example (i): A writes a will for Z, intentionally changing the legatee’s name. A deceives Z into signing the altered will. A has committed forgery.

qas.question: What is the forgery committed in Example (i)?

answers.text: A writes a will for Z, changing the legatee’s name and deceiving Z into signing the altered will.

paragraphs.context: Example (j): A writes a letter and signs it with B’s name without authorization, to fraudulently claim that A is in distressed circumstances and seek alms. A has committed forgery.

qas.question: What is the forgery committed in Example (j)?

answers.text: A signs a letter with B’s name without authorization, claiming distressed circumstances to seek alms.

paragraphs.context: Section 336 expands on the definition and punishment for forgery: False Documents or Electronic Records with Intent to Cause Harm. Forgery involves creating or altering a false document or electronic record with the intent to cause damage or injury: To the public or any individual. To support a claim or title. To cause someone to part with property. To enter into a contract (express or implied). To commit fraud or facilitate fraud.

qas.question: What constitutes forgery in the context of false documents or electronic records with intent to cause harm?

answers.text: Creating or altering a false document or electronic record with the intent to cause damage or injury to the public, an individual, or for fraud purposes.

paragraphs.context: Punishments for Forgery: For general forgery (making a false document or electronic record), the punishment is: Imprisonment for a term up to two years, or a fine, or both. Forgery with Intent to Cheat: If the forged document or electronic record is intended to be used for cheating, the punishment is: Imprisonment for a term that may extend to seven years, along with a fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for general forgery and forgery with intent to cheat?

answers.text: For general forgery: imprisonment up to two years, a fine, or both. For forgery with intent to cheat: imprisonment up to seven years and a fine.

paragraphs.context: Explanation and Additional Illustrations: Forgery Through False Names or Antedating Documents. Illustration (k): A writes a letter in B's name certifying A’s character, with the intention of deceiving Z to obtain employment. A commits forgery because A intended to deceive Z into forming an employment contract based on the forged certificate.

qas.question: What is the forgery committed in Illustration (k)?

answers.text: A writes a letter in B's name to deceive Z into obtaining employment, committing forgery.

paragraphs.context: Explanation 1 - Signing Own Name: A person’s signature of their own name may constitute forgery if it is intended to deceive. Example (a): A signs their own name on a bill of exchange, intending that others believe the bill was drawn by someone else with the same name. A commits forgery.

qas.question: Can signing one's own name be considered forgery?

answers.text: Yes, if it is intended to deceive others into believing it was signed by someone else with the same name.

paragraphs.context: Explanation 2 - Forgery in the Name of Fictional or Deceased Persons: Making a document in the name of a fictitious person or a deceased person, intending to mislead others into believing it was created by the person during their lifetime, can be forgery. Example: A draws a bill of exchange upon a fictitious person and fraudulently accepts it in that name to negotiate the bill. A commits forgery.

qas.question: What is an example of forgery in the name of fictional or deceased persons?

answers.text: A draws a bill of exchange in the name of a fictitious person and fraudulently accepts it to negotiate the bill.

paragraphs.context: Explanation 3 - Electronic Signature Definition: The term 'affixing electronic signature' is defined in the Information Technology Act, 2000, which helps clarify the legal aspect of electronic records and documents.

qas.question: What is the definition of affixing an electronic signature?

answers.text: The term 'affixing electronic signature' is defined in the Information Technology Act, 2000, which clarifies the legal aspect of electronic records.

paragraphs.context: Examples of Forgery in Other Contexts: Example (b): A writes the word 'accepted' on a piece of paper and signs it with Z’s name, intending for B to draw a bill of exchange on it and negotiate it as if it were accepted by Z. A commits forgery, and B is also guilty if they knowingly participate in the deception.

qas.question: What is the forgery committed in Example (b)?

answers.text: A writes 'accepted' on a piece of paper, signs it with Z's name, and intends for B to use it to deceive others into negotiating the bill.

paragraphs.context: Example (c): A picks up a bill of exchange payable to the order of someone else with the same name, and A endorses it intending to deceive others into believing it was endorsed by the intended person. A commits forgery.

qas.question: What is the forgery committed in Example (c)?

answers.text: A endorses a bill of exchange payable to someone else with the same name, intending to deceive others.

paragraphs.context: Example (d): B colludes with Z to execute a lease of an estate after it was seized by A under legal execution, dating the lease six months earlier than the seizure to make it appear valid before the property was taken. B commits forgery by antedating the lease.

qas.question: What is the forgery committed in Example (d)?

answers.text: B colludes with Z to antedate a lease of an estate seized by A, making it appear valid before the seizure.

paragraphs.context: Example (e): A, anticipating insolvency, lodges goods with B and fraudulently creates a promissory note, backdating it to make it seem like a legitimate transaction before insolvency, in an attempt to defraud creditors. A commits forgery.

qas.question: What is the forgery committed in Example (e)?

answers.text: A creates a backdated promissory note to deceive creditors into believing the transaction occurred before insolvency.

paragraphs.context: Section 336(4) - Harm to Reputation. Forgery with Intent to Harm Reputation: If the forged document or electronic record is created with the intent to harm the reputation of any party, or if the person knows it is likely to be used for such purpose, the punishment is: Imprisonment for a term up to three years, and a fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for forgery with intent to harm reputation?

answers.text: Imprisonment for up to three years, and a fine.

paragraphs.context: Section 337 - Forging Court Documents or Identity Documents. Forgery of Court or Government Documents: Forgery of a document or electronic record that purports to be a court record, identity document (such as voter ID or Aadhaar card), birth, marriage, or burial register, document by a public servant in their official capacity, or any related document (such as authority to institute a suit or to defend, etc.) is punishable by: Imprisonment for a term up to seven years, and a fine. Explanation: The term “register” includes any list, data, or record maintained in electronic form, as per the Information Technology Act, 2000.

qas.question: What is the punishment for forgery of court or government documents?

answers.text: Imprisonment for up to seven years, and a fine.

paragraphs.context: Section 338 - Forgery of Valuable Documents. Forgery of Valuable Documents: Forgery of valuable documents such as: A valuable security (like bonds, shares). A will. Authority to adopt a son. Documents authorizing the transfer or receipt of valuable securities, money, or property. Acquittances or receipts acknowledging the payment of money or delivery of property. Punishment for this type of forgery is severe: Imprisonment for life or up to ten years, along with a fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for forgery of valuable documents?

answers.text: Imprisonment for life or up to ten years, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: Section 339 - Possession of Forged Documents. Possession of Forged Documents: If a person possesses any forged document or electronic record, knowing that it is forged, and intends to use it fraudulently or dishonestly as genuine, the punishment depends on the type of document: Forged Court or Government Documents (as described in Section 337): Imprisonment for up to seven years, along with a fine. Forged Valuable Documents (as described in Section 338): Imprisonment for life, or up to seven years, along with a fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for possession of forged documents?

answers.text: Imprisonment for up to seven years, and a fine for forged Court or Government documents. Imprisonment for life or up to seven years, along with a fine for forged valuable documents.

paragraphs.context: Section 340 - Use of Forged Documents. Fraudulent Use of Forged Documents: If someone fraudulently or dishonestly uses a document or electronic record that they know or have reason to believe is forged, they are punishable in the same manner as if they themselves had forged the document.

qas.question: What is the punishment for fraudulent use of forged documents?

answers.text: They are punishable in the same manner as if they themselves had forged the document.

paragraphs.context: Section 341 - Counterfeiting Seals, Plates, or Instruments. Counterfeiting Seals or Instruments for Forgery: Making or counterfeiting any seal, plate, or instrument with the intent to use it for committing forgery under Section 338 (e.g., forging valuable documents) is punishable by: Imprisonment for life or up to seven years, and a fine. Counterfeiting for Other Forgeries: Making or counterfeiting a seal or instrument to commit forgery (not under Section 338) is punishable by: Imprisonment for up to seven years, and a fine. Possession of Counterfeit Seals or Instruments: Possession of any counterfeit seal, plate, or instrument (knowing it to be counterfeit) is punishable by: Imprisonment for up to three years, and a fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for counterfeiting seals or instruments?

answers.text: Imprisonment for life or up to seven years, and a fine for counterfeiting seals or instruments for forgery. Imprisonment for up to seven years, and a fine for counterfeiting for other forgeries. Imprisonment for up to three years, and a fine for possession of counterfeit seals or instruments.

paragraphs.context: Section 341 - Use of Counterfeit Seals or Instruments. Fraudulent Use of Counterfeit Seals, Plates, or Instruments: Using any counterfeit seal, plate, or instrument (knowing it to be counterfeit) as though it were genuine is punishable in the same manner as if the person had made or counterfeited the seal, plate, or instrument. Punishment: The person is subject to the same penalties as for counterfeiting.

qas.question: What is the punishment for using counterfeit seals or instruments?

answers.text: The person is subject to the same penalties as for counterfeiting.

paragraphs.context: Section 342 - Counterfeiting Devices for Authenticity. Counterfeiting Devices or Marks for Authenticity: Counterfeiting a device or mark on any material (for documents described in Section 338) that is used to authenticate documents, with the intent to give the appearance of authenticity to a forged document is punishable by: Imprisonment for life or up to seven years, and a fine. Possession of Counterfeited Device or Mark: Possessing material with such counterfeit devices or marks, intending them to be used for forgery, is also punishable in the same manner as above.

qas.question: What is the punishment for counterfeiting devices or marks for authenticity?

answers.text: Imprisonment for life or up to seven years, and a fine.

paragraphs.context: Section 343 - Defacing or Destroying Documents. Defacing, Destroying, or Cancelling Important Documents: Fraudulently or dishonestly canceling, destroying, defacing, or secreting documents such as a will, authority to adopt a son, or valuable securities (or attempting to do so) with intent to cause harm or injury, is punishable by: Imprisonment for life or up to seven years, and a fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for defacing or destroying important documents?

answers.text: Imprisonment for life or up to seven years, and a fine.

paragraphs.context: Section 344 - Forging or Altering Documents in Employment. Clerks, Officers, or Servants Falsifying Documents: Clerks, officers, or servants, or those acting in such capacity, who wilfully and with intent to defraud: Destroy, alter, mutilate, or falsify documents, records, or accounts belonging to their employer, or Make false entries or alter/remove material particulars from such documents/accounts. The punishment is: Imprisonment for up to seven years, or fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for falsifying documents in employment?

answers.text: Imprisonment for up to seven years, or fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: Section 342(2) - Counterfeiting Devices for Other Documents. Counterfeiting Devices for Documents Other than Those in Section 338: Counterfeiting a device or mark on any material used to authenticate documents or electronic records (other than those described in Section 338) with the intent to forge documents is punishable by: Imprisonment for up to seven years, and a fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for counterfeiting devices for documents other than those in Section 338?

answers.text: Imprisonment for up to seven years, and a fine.

paragraphs.context: Section 345 - Property Marks. Definition of Property Mark: A property mark denotes that movable property belongs to a particular person. Using a false property mark refers to marking movable property, goods, or containers in a manner likely to make others believe that the property belongs to someone other than the actual owner. Punishment for Using a False Property Mark: Imprisonment for up to one year, or fine, or both, unless the accused proves they did not intend to defraud.

qas.question: What is the punishment for using a false property mark?

answers.text: Imprisonment for up to one year, or fine, or both, unless the accused proves they did not intend to defraud.

paragraphs.context: Section 346 - Removal, Destruction, or Defacing Property Marks. Removal or Alteration of Property Marks: Removing, destroying, defacing, or adding to any property mark with the intention or knowledge that it may cause injury to any person is punishable by: Imprisonment for up to one year, or fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for removing or altering a property mark?

answers.text: Imprisonment for up to one year, or fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: Section 347 - Counterfeiting Property Marks. Counterfeiting a Property Mark: Counterfeiting any property mark used by any other person is punishable by: Imprisonment for up to two years, or fine, or both. Counterfeiting a Property Mark Used by a Public Servant: Counterfeiting any property mark used by a public servant or using a counterfeit mark denoting authenticity or quality (e.g., goods manufactured by a specific person, or goods entitled to exemptions) is punishable by: Imprisonment for up to three years, and fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for counterfeiting a property mark?

answers.text: Imprisonment for up to two years, or fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: Section 348 - Possessing Instruments for Counterfeiting Property Marks. Possessing Instruments or Marks for Counterfeiting: Making or possessing any die, plate, or instrument to counterfeit a property mark, or possessing a property mark to indicate ownership of goods that don’t belong to the owner, is punishable by: Imprisonment for up to three years, or fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for possessing instruments for counterfeiting property marks?

answers.text: Imprisonment for up to three years, or fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: Section 349 - Selling Goods with Counterfeit Property Marks. Selling or Possessing Goods with Counterfeit Property Marks: Selling or possessing goods with counterfeit property marks, or marks affixed to containers, unless the accused can prove they acted innocently, will be punished by: Imprisonment for up to one year, or fine, or both. Defenses: The defendant can defend by proving that they had no reason to suspect the genuineness of the mark, or that they provided all the relevant information when requested, or that they acted innocently.

qas.question: What is the punishment for selling goods with counterfeit property marks?

answers.text: Imprisonment for up to one year, or fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: Section 350 - False Marks on Receptacles or Goods. False Marks on Receptacles or Goods: Making false marks on containers or goods in a manner likely to deceive others (e.g., to mislead public servants or others about the contents or quality of goods) is punishable by: Imprisonment for up to three years, or fine, or both. Use of False Marks: Using false marks as described above also carries the same punishment unless the accused can prove they acted without intent to defraud.

qas.question: What is the punishment for making false marks on receptacles or goods?

answers.text: Imprisonment for up to three years, or fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: Lurking House-Trespass: Lurking house-trespass is committed when someone engages in house-trespass while taking precautions to conceal their actions from a person who has the right to exclude or eject the trespasser from the building, tent, or vessel involved.

qas.question: What constitutes lurking house-trespass?

answers.text: Lurking house-trespass occurs when someone engages in house-trespass while taking precautions to conceal their actions from the person who has the right to exclude or eject the trespasser.

paragraphs.context: Housebreaking Defined: A person commits housebreaking if they commit house-trespass by entering or exiting a house or part of it in any of the following ways: Creating a Passage: Entering or exiting through a passage made by the trespasser or an accomplice. Unauthorized Passage: Entering or exiting through a passage not intended by anyone other than the trespasser or accomplice, such as scaling or climbing over walls. Opening a Passage: Entering or exiting through a passage opened by the trespasser or accomplice that was not meant to be opened by the occupier. Opening a Lock: Entering or exiting by opening a lock to facilitate the house-trespass. Using Force or Assault: Entering or exiting by using criminal force or committing an assault, or by threatening to do so. Unfastening a Locked Passage: Entering or exiting by a passage that was fastened against entry but was unfastened by the trespasser or accomplice.

qas.question: What constitutes housebreaking?

answers.text: Housebreaking occurs when someone commits house-trespass by entering or exiting a house or part of it by creating a passage, unauthorized passage, opening a passage, opening a lock, using force or assault, or unfastening a locked passage.

paragraphs.context: Mischief by Killing, Poisoning, or Maiming Animals: Whoever commits mischief by killing, poisoning, maiming, or rendering any animal useless will be punished with imprisonment for up to 5 years, a fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for mischief by killing, poisoning, or maiming animals?

answers.text: The punishment for mischief by killing, poisoning, or maiming animals is imprisonment for up to 5 years, a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: A consent is not such a consent as is intended by any section of this Sanhita–– (a) if the consent is given by a person under fear of injury, or under a misconception of fact, and if the person doing the act knows, or has reason to believe, that the consent was given in consequence of such fear or misconception; or (b) if the consent is given by a person who, from unsoundness of mind, or intoxication, is unable to understand the nature and consequence of that to which he gives his consent; or (c) unless the contrary appears from the context, if the consent is given by a person who is under twelve years of age.

qas.question: When is consent not valid according to the Sanhita?

answers.text: If the consent is given by a person under fear of injury, or under a misconception of fact; if it is given by a person of unsound mind or intoxicated; or if the person is under twelve years of age.

qas.question: What happens if consent is given under fear of injury or misconception of fact?

answers.text: The consent is not valid if the person doing the act knows, or has reason to believe, that the consent was given in consequence of such fear or misconception.

qas.question: Is consent valid if given by a person of unsound mind or intoxication?

answers.text: No, if the person is unable to understand the nature and consequence of that to which he gives his consent.

qas.question: Is consent valid if given by a person under twelve years of age?

answers.text: No, unless the contrary appears from the context.

paragraphs.context: The exceptions in sections 25, 26 and 27 do not extend to acts which are offences independently of any harm which they may cause, or be intended to cause, or be known to be likely to cause, to the person giving the consent, or on whose behalf the consent is given.

qas.question: Do the exceptions in sections 25, 26, and 27 apply to acts that are offences independently of harm caused?

answers.text: No, they do not extend to acts which are offences independently of any harm caused.

paragraphs.context: Causing miscarriage (unless caused in good faith for the purpose of saving the life of the woman) is an offence independently of any harm which it may cause or be intended to cause to the woman. Therefore, it is not an offence “by reason of such harm”; and the consent of the woman or of her guardian to the causing of such miscarriage does not justify the act.

qas.question: Is causing miscarriage an offence even with the woman's consent?

answers.text: Yes, causing miscarriage is an offence independently of any harm, unless caused in good faith for the purpose of saving the life of the woman.

paragraphs.context: Nothing is an offence by reason of any harm which it may cause to a person for whose benefit it is done in good faith, even without that person’s consent, if the circumstances are such that it is impossible for that person to signify consent, or if that person is incapable of giving consent, and has no guardian or other person in lawful charge of him from whom it is possible to obtain consent in time for the thing to be done with benefit.

qas.question: When is an act not an offence even without the person’s consent?

answers.text: If the act is done in good faith for the person’s benefit, and it is impossible for that person to signify consent or obtain consent from a guardian in time.

paragraphs.context: Z is thrown from his horse, and is insensible. A, a surgeon, finds that Z requires to be trepanned. A, not intending Z’s death, but in good faith, for Z’s benefit, performs the trepan before Z recovers his power of judging for himself. A has committed no offence.

qas.question: Why is A not guilty of an offence for performing surgery on Z without consent?

answers.text: Because A acted in good faith for Z’s benefit before Z recovered his power of judging for himself.

paragraphs.context: Z is carried off by a tiger. A fires at the tiger knowing it to be likely that the shot may kill Z, but not intending to kill Z, and in good faith intending Z’s benefit. A’s bullet gives Z a mortal wound. A has committed no offence.

qas.question: Why is A not guilty of an offence for accidentally killing Z while firing at a tiger?

answers.text: Because A fired at the tiger in good faith intending Z’s benefit, and did not intend to kill Z.

paragraphs.context: A, a surgeon, sees a child suffer an accident which is likely to prove fatal unless an operation be immediately performed. There is no time to apply to the child’s guardian. A performs the operation in spite of the entreaties of the child, intending, in good faith, the child’s benefit. A has committed no offence.

qas.question: Why is A not guilty of an offence for performing an operation on a child without guardian consent?

answers.text: Because A acted in good faith intending the child’s benefit, and there was no time to obtain guardian consent.

paragraphs.context: A is in a house which is on fire, with Z, a child. People below hold out a blanket. A drops the child from the house top, knowing it to be likely that the fall may kill the child, but not intending to kill the child, and intending, in good faith, the child’s benefit. Here, even if the child is killed by the fall, A has committed no offence.

qas.question: Why is A not guilty of an offence for dropping Z from a burning house?

answers.text: Because A acted in good faith intending the child’s benefit and did not intend to kill the child.

paragraphs.context: Mere pecuniary benefit is not benefit within the meaning of sections 26, 27 and this section.

qas.question: Is pecuniary benefit considered a benefit under sections 26, 27, and 30?

answers.text: No, mere pecuniary benefit is not considered a benefit.

paragraphs.context: Whenever any person, who is absent would be liable to be punished as an abettor, is present when the act or offence for which he would be punishable in consequence of the abetment is committed, he shall be deemed to have committed such act or offence.

qas.question: What happens if a person who is absent and liable to punishment as an abettor is present when the offence is committed?

answers.text: He shall be deemed to have committed such act or offence.

paragraphs.context: Whoever abets the commission of an offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life, shall, if that offence be not committed in consequence of the abetment, and no express provision is made under this Sanhita for the punishment of such abetment, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine; and if any act for which the abettor is liable in consequence of the abetment, and which causes hurt to any person, is done, the abettor shall be liable to imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to fourteen years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for abetment of an offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life if the offence is not committed?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What happens if an act in consequence of abetment causes hurt to a person?

answers.text: The abettor shall be liable to imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to fourteen years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: A instigates B to murder Z. The offence is not committed. If B had murdered Z, he would have been subject to the punishment of death or imprisonment for life. Therefore, A is liable to imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years and also to a fine; and if any hurt be done to Z in consequence of the abetment, he will be liable to imprisonment for a term which may extend to fourteen years, and to fine.

qas.question: What is A's liability if he instigates B to murder Z and the offence is not committed?

answers.text: A is liable to imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years and also to a fine.

qas.question: What is A's liability if hurt is caused to Z in consequence of abetment?

answers.text: He will be liable to imprisonment for a term which may extend to fourteen years, and to fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever abets an offence punishable with imprisonment shall, if that offence be not committed in consequence of the abetment, and no express provision is made under this Sanhita for the punishment of such abetment, be punished with imprisonment of any description provided for that offence for a term which may extend to one-fourth part of the longest term provided for that offence; or with such fine as is provided for that offence, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for abetment of an offence punishable with imprisonment if the offence is not committed?

answers.text: Imprisonment of any description provided for that offence for a term which may extend to one-fourth part of the longest term provided for that offence; or with such fine as is provided for that offence, or with both.

paragraphs.context: If the abettor or the person abetted is a public servant, whose duty it is to prevent the commission of such offence, the abettor shall be punished with imprisonment of any description provided for that offence, for a term which may extend to one-half of the longest term provided for that offence, or with such fine as is provided for the offence, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment if the abettor is a public servant whose duty it is to prevent the commission of the offence?

answers.text: Imprisonment of any description provided for that offence, for a term which may extend to one-half of the longest term provided for that offence, or with such fine as is provided for the offence, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever abets the commission of an offence by the public generally or by any number or class of persons exceeding ten, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years and with fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for abetting the commission of an offence by the public or by more than ten persons?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years and with fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever intending to facilitate or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby facilitate the commission of an offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life, voluntarily conceals by any act or omission, or by the use of encryption or any other information hiding tool, the existence of a design to commit such offence shall,–– (a) if that offence be committed, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years; or (b) if the offence be not committed, with imprisonment of either description, for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for concealing a design to commit an offence punishable with death or life imprisonment if the offence is committed?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years.

qas.question: What is the punishment for concealing a design to commit an offence punishable with death or life imprisonment if the offence is not committed?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description, for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, being a public servant, intending to facilitate or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby facilitate the commission of an offence which it is his duty as such public servant to prevent, voluntarily conceals, by any act or omission, the existence of a design to commit such offence shall,–– (a) if the offence be committed, be punished with imprisonment of any description provided for the offence, for a term which may extend to one-half of the longest term of such imprisonment, or with such fine as is provided for that offence, or with both; or (b) if the offence be not committed, shall be punished with imprisonment of any description provided for the offence for a term which may extend to one-fourth part of the longest term of such imprisonment or with such fine as is provided for the offence, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for a public servant concealing a design to commit an offence if the offence is committed?

answers.text: Imprisonment of any description provided for the offence, for a term which may extend to one-half of the longest term of such imprisonment, or with such fine as is provided for that offence, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for a public servant concealing a design to commit an offence if the offence is not committed?

answers.text: Imprisonment of any description provided for the offence for a term which may extend to one-fourth part of the longest term of such imprisonment or with such fine as is provided for the offence, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Cheating and Punishments: General Cheating: Anyone who cheats is subject to imprisonment for up to 3 years, a fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for general cheating?

answers.text: The punishment for general cheating is imprisonment for up to 3 years, a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: (29) “reason to believe”.—A person is said to have “reason to believe” a thing, if he has sufficient cause to believe that thing but not otherwise;

qas.question: What does 'reason to believe' mean as per this Sanhita?

answers.text: A person is said to have 'reason to believe' a thing, if he has sufficient cause to believe that thing but not otherwise.

paragraphs.context: (30) “special law” means a law applicable to a particular subject;

qas.question: What is the definition of 'special law' in this Sanhita?

answers.text: A law applicable to a particular subject.

paragraphs.context: (31) “valuable security” means a document which is, or purports to be, a document whereby any legal right is created, extended, transferred, restricted, extinguished or released, or whereby any person acknowledges that he lies under legal liability, or has not a certain legal right.

qas.question: What is the meaning of 'valuable security' in this Sanhita?

answers.text: A document which is, or purports to be, a document whereby any legal right is created, extended, transferred, restricted, extinguished or released, or whereby any person acknowledges that he lies under legal liability, or has not a certain legal right.

qas.question: Give an example of a 'valuable security' as per this Sanhita.

answers.text: A writes his name on the back of a bill of exchange. As the effect of this endorsement is to transfer the right to the bill to any person who may become the lawful holder of it, the endorsement is a 'valuable security'.

paragraphs.context: (32) “vessel” means anything made for the conveyance by water of human beings or of property;

qas.question: What does 'vessel' mean in this Sanhita?

answers.text: Anything made for the conveyance by water of human beings or of property.

paragraphs.context: (33) “voluntarily”.—A person is said to cause an effect 'voluntarily' when he causes it by means whereby he intended to cause it, or by means which, at the time of employing those means, he knew or had reason to believe to be likely to cause it.

qas.question: What is the definition of 'voluntarily' in this Sanhita?

answers.text: A person is said to cause an effect 'voluntarily' when he causes it by means whereby he intended to cause it, or by means which, at the time of employing those means, he knew or had reason to believe to be likely to cause it.

paragraphs.context: Illustration: A sets fire, by night, to an inhabited house in a large town, for the purpose of facilitating a robbery and thus causes the death of a person. Here, A may not have intended to cause death; and may even be sorry that death has been caused by his act; yet, if he knew that he was likely to cause death, he has caused death voluntarily;

qas.question: What is an example of causing an effect 'voluntarily' as per this Sanhita?

answers.text: A sets fire, by night, to an inhabited house in a large town, for the purpose of facilitating a robbery and thus causes the death of a person.

paragraphs.context: (34) “will” means any testamentary document;

qas.question: How is 'will' defined in this Sanhita?

answers.text: Any testamentary document.

paragraphs.context: (35) “woman” means a female human being of any age;

qas.question: What is the definition of 'woman' in this Sanhita?

qas.question: What does 'wrongful gain' mean as per this Sanhita?

answers.text: Words and expressions used but not defined in this Sanhita but defined in the Information Technology Act, 2000 and the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023 shall have the meanings respectively assigned to them in that Act and Sanhita.

paragraphs.context: For the purposes of this sub-section, 'recognised welfare institution or organisation' means a social welfare institution or organisation recognised in this behalf by the Central Government or the State Government.

answers.text: A social welfare institution or organisation recognised in this behalf by the Central Government or the State Government.

paragraphs.context: Whoever prints or publishes any matter in relation to any proceeding before a Court with respect to an offence referred to in section 72 without the previous permission of such Court shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What punishment is prescribed for printing or publishing court proceedings without permission?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any woman, intending to outrage or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby outrage her modesty, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than one year but which may extend to five years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the minimum punishment for assaulting a woman with intent to outrage her modesty?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than one year.

paragraphs.context: Any man who commits the offence specified in clause (i) or clause (ii) or clause (iii) of sub-section (1) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for committing offences under clauses (i), (ii), or (iii) of sub-section (1)?

answers.text: Rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any woman or abets such act with the intention of disrobing or compelling her to be naked, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than three years but which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for assaulting a woman with the intent to disrobe?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than three years but which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever watches, or captures the image of a woman engaging in a private act in circumstances where she would usually have the expectation of not being observed either by the perpetrator or by any other person at the behest of the perpetrator or disseminates such image shall be punished on first conviction with imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than one year, but which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for a first conviction under voyeurism?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than one year, but which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.

data.title: Indian Penal Code - Assault on Grave and Sudden Provocation

paragraphs.context: 136. Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person on grave and sudden provocation given by that person, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both. Explanation.—This section is subject to the same Explanation as section 131.

qas.question: What is the punishment for assault or criminal force under Section 136 when it occurs on grave and sudden provocation?

answers.text: The punishment can be simple imprisonment for up to one month, a fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

qas.question: What does the Explanation in Section 136 refer to?

answers.text: The Explanation refers to the same conditions as those mentioned in Section 131.

data.title: Offences Relating to Religion and Property

paragraphs.context: Whoever, with the intention of wounding the feelings of any person, or of insulting the religion of any person, or with the knowledge that the feelings of any person are likely to be wounded, or that the religion of any person is likely to be insulted thereby, commits any trespass in any place of worship or on any place of sepulchre, or any place set apart for the performance of funeral rites or as a depository for the remains of the dead, or offers any indignity to any human corpse, or causes disturbance to any persons assembled for the performance of funeral ceremonies, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for trespassing in places of worship or sepulchres under Section 301?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, with the deliberate intention of wounding the religious feelings of any person, utters any word or makes any sound in the hearing of that person or makes any gesture in the sight of that person or places any object in the sight of that person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for wounding religious feelings through words or gestures under Section 302?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, intending to take dishonestly any movable property out of the possession of any person without that person’s consent, moves that property in order to such taking, is said to commit theft. Explanation 1.—A thing so long as it is attached to the earth, not being movable property, is not the subject of theft; but it becomes capable of being the subject of theft as soon as it is severed from the earth. Explanation 2.—A moving effected by the same act which affects the severance may be a theft. Explanation 3.—A person is said to cause a thing to move by removing an obstacle which prevented it from moving or by separating it from any other thing, as well as by actually moving it. Explanation 4.—A person, who by any means causes an animal to move, is said to move that animal, and to move everything which, in consequence of the motion so caused, is moved by that animal. Explanation 5.—The consent mentioned in this section may be express or implied, and may be given either by the person in possession, or by any person having for that purpose authority either express or implied.

qas.question: What constitutes theft under Section 303?

answers.text: Intending to take dishonestly any movable property out of the possession of any person without that person’s consent, moves that property in order to such taking.

qas.question: When does a thing become the subject of theft under Explanation 1?

answers.text: As soon as it is severed from the earth.

qas.question: What does Explanation 3 state about causing a thing to move?

answers.text: A person is said to cause a thing to move by removing an obstacle which prevented it from moving or by separating it from any other thing, as well as by actually moving it.

paragraphs.context: Illustrations: (a) A cuts down a tree on Z’s ground, with the intention of dishonestly taking the tree out of Z’s possession without Z’s consent. Here, as soon as A has severed the tree in order to such taking, he has committed theft. (b) A puts a bait for dogs in his pocket, and thus induces Z’s dog to follow it. Here, if A’s intention be dishonestly to take the dog out of Z’s possession without Z’s consent. A has committed theft as soon as Z’s dog has begun to follow A. (c) A meets a bullock carrying a box of treasure. He drives the bullock in a certain direction, in order that he may dishonestly take the treasure. As soon as the bullock begins to move, A has committed theft of the treasure. (d) A being Z’s servant, and entrusted by Z with the care of Z’s plate, dishonestly runs away with the plate, without Z’s consent. A has committed theft. (e) Z, going on a journey, entrusts his plate to A, the keeper of a warehouse, till Z shall return. A carries the plate to a goldsmith and sells it. Here the plate was not in Z’s possession. It could not therefore be taken out of Z’s possession, and A has not committed theft, though he may have committed criminal breach of trust.

qas.question: What constitutes theft in Illustration (a)?

answers.text: As soon as A has severed the tree in order to such taking, he has committed theft.

qas.question: What is described in Illustration (b) regarding theft?

answers.text: A puts a bait for dogs in his pocket, and thus induces Z’s dog to follow it. Here, if A’s intention be dishonestly to take the dog out of Z’s possession without Z’s consent. A has committed theft as soon as Z’s dog has begun to follow A.

qas.question: What is stated in Illustration (e) about criminal breach of trust?

answers.text: The plate was not in Z’s possession. It could not therefore be taken out of Z’s possession, and A has not committed theft, though he may have committed criminal breach of trust.

paragraphs.context: Mischief by Fire or Explosives: If someone uses fire or explosives to cause damage to property (including agricultural produce), the punishment is: Imprisonment for up to 7 years, a fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for mischief involving fire or explosives?

answers.text: The punishment for mischief involving fire or explosives is imprisonment for up to 7 years, a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: Where anything which is an offence is made up of parts, any of which parts is itself an offence, the offender shall not be punished with the punishment of more than one of such his offences, unless it be so expressly provided. Where anything is an offence falling within two or more separate definitions of any law in force for the time being by which offences are defined or punished, or several acts, of which one or more than one would by itself or themselves constitute an offence, constitute, when combined, a different offence, the offender shall not be punished with a more severe punishment than the Court which tries him could award for any one of such offences.

qas.question: What happens when an offence is made up of parts, each of which is itself an offence?

answers.text: The offender shall not be punished with the punishment of more than one of such his offences, unless it be so expressly provided.

qas.question: What is the punishment when an offence falls under multiple definitions of law?

answers.text: The offender shall not be punished with a more severe punishment than the Court which tries him could award for any one of such offences.

qas.question: What happens if several acts constitute a different offence when combined?

answers.text: The offender shall not be punished with a more severe punishment than the Court which tries him could award for any one of such offences.

paragraphs.context: A gives Z fifty strokes with a stick. Here A may have committed the offence of voluntarily causing hurt to Z by the whole beating, and also by each of the blows which make up the whole beating. If A were liable to punishment for every blow, he might be imprisoned for fifty years, one for each blow. But he is liable only to one punishment for the whole beating. But, if, while A is beating Z, Y interferes, and A intentionally strikes Y, here, as the blow given to Y is no part of the act whereby A voluntarily causes hurt to Z, A is liable to one punishment for voluntarily causing hurt to Z, and to another for the blow given to Y.

qas.question: How many punishments is A liable for if he gives Z fifty strokes with a stick?

answers.text: He is liable only to one punishment for the whole beating.

qas.question: What happens if A intentionally strikes Y while beating Z?

answers.text: A is liable to one punishment for voluntarily causing hurt to Z, and to another for the blow given to Y.

paragraphs.context: In all cases in which judgment is given that a person is guilty of one of several offences specified in the judgment, but that it is doubtful of which of these offences he is guilty, the offender shall be punished for the offence for which the lowest punishment is provided if the same punishment is not provided for all.

qas.question: How is an offender punished if it is doubtful which offence he is guilty of?

answers.text: The offender shall be punished for the offence for which the lowest punishment is provided if the same punishment is not provided for all.

paragraphs.context: Whenever any person is convicted of an offence for which under this Sanhita the Court has power to sentence him to rigorous imprisonment, the Court may, by its sentence, order that the offender shall be kept in solitary confinement for any portion or portions of the imprisonment to which he is sentenced, not exceeding three months in the whole.

qas.question: What is the maximum duration of solitary confinement for an offender?

answers.text: Not exceeding three months in the whole.

paragraphs.context: A time not exceeding one month if the term of imprisonment shall not exceed six months; a time not exceeding two months if the term of imprisonment shall exceed six months and shall not exceed one year; a time not exceeding three months if the term of imprisonment shall exceed one year.

qas.question: What is the maximum duration of solitary confinement if the imprisonment term does not exceed six months?

answers.text: A time not exceeding one month.

qas.question: What is the maximum duration of solitary confinement if the imprisonment term is between six months and one year?

answers.text: A time not exceeding two months.

qas.question: What is the maximum duration of solitary confinement if the imprisonment term exceeds one year?

answers.text: A time not exceeding three months.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, having been convicted by a Court in India, of an offence punishable under Chapter X or Chapter XVII of this Sanhita with imprisonment of either description for a term of three years or upwards, shall be guilty of any offence punishable under either of those Chapters with like imprisonment for the like term, shall be subject for every such subsequent offence to imprisonment for life, or to imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years.

qas.question: What is the enhanced punishment for subsequent offences under Chapter X or Chapter XVII?

answers.text: Imprisonment for life, or to imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years.

paragraphs.context: Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who is, or who by reason of a mistake of fact and not by reason of a mistake of law in good faith believes himself to be, bound by law to do it.

qas.question: When is an act not considered an offence due to a mistake of fact?

answers.text: When a person in good faith believes himself to be bound by law to do it.

paragraphs.context: A, a soldier, fires on a mob by the order of his superior officer, in conformity with the commands of the law. A has committed no offence.

qas.question: Why has A committed no offence when firing on a mob?

answers.text: Because A acted in conformity with the commands of the law and by order of his superior officer.

paragraphs.context: A, an officer of a Court, being ordered by that Court to arrest Y, and, after due enquiry, believing Z to be Y, arrests Z. A has committed no offence.

qas.question: Why has A committed no offence when mistakenly arresting Z?

answers.text: Because A, after due enquiry, believed Z to be Y.

paragraphs.context: Nothing is an offence which is done by a Judge when acting judicially in the exercise of any power which is, or which in good faith he believes to be, given to him by law.

qas.question: When is an act by a Judge not considered an offence?

answers.text: When acting judicially in the exercise of any power which he believes in good faith to be given to him by law.

paragraphs.context: Criminal Trespass Defined: Criminal trespass occurs when someone enters into or remains upon property in the possession of another person with the intent to commit an offense or to intimidate, insult, or annoy the person in possession of the property. A person who unlawfully remains on such property with intent to commit an offense or intimidate the person is also considered to be committing criminal trespass.

qas.question: What constitutes criminal trespass?

answers.text: Criminal trespass occurs when someone enters or remains upon property in the possession of another person with the intent to commit an offense or to intimidate, insult, or annoy the person in possession of the property.

paragraphs.context: House-Trespass: If criminal trespass is committed by entering or remaining in any building, tent, vessel used as a human dwelling, or a building used as a place of worship or for the custody of property, it is considered house-trespass.

qas.question: What is considered house-trespass?

answers.text: House-trespass occurs if criminal trespass is committed by entering or remaining in any building, tent, vessel used as a human dwelling, or a building used as a place of worship or for the custody of property.

paragraphs.context: Punishments for Criminal Trespass: Imprisonment for up to 3 months, a fine of up to 5,000 rupees, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for criminal trespass?

answers.text: The punishment for criminal trespass is imprisonment for up to 3 months, a fine of up to 5,000 rupees, or both.

paragraphs.context: Punishments for House-Trespass: Imprisonment for up to 1 year, a fine of up to 5,000 rupees, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for house-trespass?

answers.text: The punishment for house-trespass is imprisonment for up to 1 year, a fine of up to 5,000 rupees, or both.

paragraphs.context: Mischief by Affecting Public Infrastructure: Affecting public roads, bridges, rivers, or navigable channels (rendering them impassable or unsafe): Up to 5 years imprisonment, a fine, or both. Acts causing inundation or obstruction to public drainage: Up to 5 years imprisonment, a fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for mischief affecting public infrastructure?

answers.text: The punishment for mischief affecting public infrastructure, including roads, bridges, rivers, or navigable channels, is up to 5 years imprisonment, a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: Explanation 2: Mischief can also be committed against property belonging to the person committing the act or jointly with others.

qas.question: Can mischief be committed against property belonging to the person committing the act?

answers.text: Yes, mischief can also be committed against property belonging to the person committing the act or jointly with others.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, being legally bound to produce or deliver up any document or electronic record to any public servant, as such, intentionally omits so to produce or deliver up the same,–– (a) shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both; (b) and where the document or electronic record is to be produced or delivered up to a Court with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for intentionally omitting to deliver a document or electronic record to a public servant?

answers.text: Simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for omitting to deliver a document to a court?

answers.text: Simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, being legally bound to give any notice or to furnish information on any subject to any public servant, as such, intentionally omits to give such notice or to furnish such information in the manner and at the time required by law,–– (a) shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both; (b) where the notice or information required to be given respects the commission of an offence, or is required for the purpose of preventing the commission of an offence, or in order to the apprehension of an offender, with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees, or with both; (c) where the notice or information required to be given is required by an order passed under section 394 of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023 with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for omitting to furnish required notice or information to a public servant?

answers.text: Simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment if the omitted information respects the commission of an offence?

answers.text: Simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for not giving information required by an order under section 394 of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, being legally bound to furnish information on any subject to any public servant, as such, furnishes, as true, information on the subject which he knows or has reason to believe to be false,–– (a) shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both; (b) where the information which he is legally bound to give respects the commission of an offence, or is required for the purpose of preventing the commission of an offence, or in order to the apprehension of an offender, with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for providing false information to a public servant?

answers.text: Simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for giving false information related to the commission of an offence?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: A, a landholder, knowing of the commission of a murder within the limits of his estate, wilfully misinforms the Magistrate of the district that the death has occurred by accident in consequence of the bite of a snake. A is guilty of the offence defined in this section.

qas.question: What does A do to misinform the Magistrate?

answers.text: Wilfully misinforms the Magistrate of the district that the death has occurred by accident in consequence of the bite of a snake.

data.title: Offences Related to Unlawful Assemblies, Riots, and Affrays

paragraphs.context: Whenever any unlawful assembly or riot takes place, the owner or occupier of the land upon which such unlawful assembly is held, or such riot is committed, and any person having or claiming an interest in such land, shall be punishable with fine not exceeding one thousand rupees, if he or his agent or manager, knowing that such offence is being or has been committed, or having reason to believe it is likely to be committed, do not give the earliest notice thereof in his or their power to the officer in charge at the nearest police station, and do not, in the case of his or their having reason to believe that it was about to be committed, use all lawful means in his or their power to prevent it and, in the event of its taking place, do not use all lawful means in his or their power to disperse or suppress the riot or unlawful assembly.

qas.question: Who is punishable if an unlawful assembly or riot occurs on their land?

answers.text: The owner or occupier of the land, and any person having or claiming an interest in such land.

qas.question: What is the maximum fine for failing to report or prevent an unlawful assembly or riot?

answers.text: One thousand rupees.

paragraphs.context: When two or more persons, by fighting in a public place, disturb the public peace, they are said to commit an affray. Whoever commits an affray, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is an affray?

answers.text: When two or more persons, by fighting in a public place, disturb the public peace.

qas.question: What is the punishment for committing an affray?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever assaults or obstructs any public servant or uses criminal force on any public servant in the discharge of his duty as such public servant in endeavouring to disperse an unlawful assembly, or to suppress a riot or affray, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine which shall not be less than twenty-five thousand rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for assaulting a public servant dispersing an unlawful assembly?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine which shall not be less than twenty-five thousand rupees, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever threatens to assault or attempts to obstruct any public servant or threatens or attempts to use criminal force to any public servant in the discharge of his duty as such public servant in endeavouring to disperse an unlawful assembly, or to suppress a riot or affray, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for threatening to obstruct a public servant dispersing an unlawful assembly?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Section 313: Anyone who is part of a group involved in regularly committing theft or robbery (not a group of dacoits) can be punished with up to seven years of rigorous imprisonment and a fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for being part of a group regularly committing theft or robbery?

answers.text: The punishment for being part of a group involved in regular theft or robbery can be up to seven years of rigorous imprisonment and a fine.

paragraphs.context: Section 314: Anyone who dishonestly takes or uses someone else's movable property, intending to keep it for themselves, can be punished with at least six months of imprisonment, up to two years, and may also be fined.

qas.question: What is the punishment for dishonestly taking someone else's property with the intent to keep it?

answers.text: The punishment for dishonestly taking someone else's movable property with the intent to keep it is at least six months of imprisonment, up to two years, and possibly a fine.

paragraphs.context:
Examples:
(a) A takes Z’s property, thinking it’s his own, but later finds out it belongs to Z. If A then keeps it for himself, he’s guilty.
(b) A, thinking he has permission from Z to borrow a book, takes it without asking. If A later sells the book, he is guilty.
(c) A and B own a horse together. A takes the horse from B to use it. But if A sells the horse and keeps the money, he is guilty.

qas.question: What are some examples of misappropriation of property?

answers.text: Examples of misappropriation include taking someone else's property, thinking it's your own, and then keeping it, or taking a property without permission and selling it.

paragraphs.context:
Explanations: Even if someone takes property intending to return it, using it for themselves makes them guilty of misappropriation.
Example: A finds a government note belonging to Z and uses it as security for a loan, intending to return it later. A has committed an offense.
If someone finds property and takes it to protect it or return it to the owner, it’s not an offense. But if they take it for themselves or don’t try to find the owner, they’re guilty.
Example: A finds a rupee on the road, not knowing who it belongs to. A has not committed an offense.
Example: A finds a letter with a bank note and figures out who it belongs to but keeps the money. A is guilty.

qas.question: When is it considered misappropriation of property?

answers.text: It is considered misappropriation if someone takes property with the intent to use it for themselves or does not make efforts to return it, even if they initially intended to return it.

paragraphs.context: In summary, if you take someone else's property with the intent to use it for yourself, or don’t make efforts to return it, it’s considered a crime.

qas.question: What is the summary of Section 314 regarding misappropriation?

answers.text: The summary of Section 314 is that taking someone else's property with the intent to use it for yourself or failing to return it is considered a crime.

data.title: Indian Penal Code - Offences Related to Elections and Counterfeiting

paragraphs.context: 176. Whoever without the general or special authority in writing of a candidate incurs or authorises expenses on account of the holding of any public meeting, or upon any advertisement, circular or publication, or in any other way whatsoever for the purpose of promoting or procuring the election of such candidate, shall be punished with fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees: Provided that if any person having incurred any such expenses not exceeding the amount of ten rupees without authority obtains within ten days from the date on which such expenses were incurred the approval in writing of the candidate, he shall be deemed to have incurred such expenses with the authority of the candidate.

qas.question: What penalty is imposed under Section 176 for incurring expenses without authority in connection with an election?

answers.text: The penalty is a fine that may extend to ten thousand rupees.

paragraphs.context: 177. Whoever being required by any law for the time being in force or any rule having the force of law to keep accounts of expenses incurred at or in connection with an election fails to keep such accounts shall be punished with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees.

qas.question: What is the punishment for failing to keep election accounts as required under Section 177?

answers.text: The punishment is a fine that may extend to five thousand rupees.

paragraphs.context: 178. Whoever counterfeits, or knowingly performs any part of the process of counterfeiting, any coin, stamp issued by Government for the purpose of revenue, currency-note or bank-note, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
