Explanation.—For the purposes of this Chapter,— (1) the expression “bank-note” means a promissory note or engagement for the payment of money to bearer on demand issued by any person carrying on the business of banking in any part of the world, or issued by or under the authority of any State or Sovereign Power, and intended to be used as equivalent to, or as a substitute for money; (2) “coin” shall have the same meaning as assigned to it in section 2 of the Coinage Act, 2011 and includes metal used for the time being as money and is stamped and issued by or under the authority of any State or Sovereign Power intended to be so used; (3) a person commits the offence of “counterfeiting Government stamp” who counterfeits by causing a genuine stamp of one denomination to appear like a genuine stamp of a different denomination; (4) a person commits the offence of counterfeiting coin who intending to practise deception, or knowing it to be likely that deception will thereby be practised, causes a genuine coin to appear like a different coin; and (5) the offence of “counterfeiting coin” includes diminishing the weight or alteration of the composition, or alteration of the appearance of the coin.

qas.question: What are the penalties for counterfeiting coins, currency-notes, or government stamps under Section 178?

answers.text: The penalties include imprisonment for life or a term of up to ten years, and a fine.

paragraphs.context: 179. Whoever imports or exports, or sells or delivers to, or buys or receives from, any other person, or otherwise traffics or uses as genuine, any forged or counterfeit coin, stamp, currency-note or bank-note, knowing or having reason to believe the same to be forged or counterfeit, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for trafficking or using forged or counterfeit currency or government stamps under Section 179?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment for life, or up to ten years, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: 180. Whoever has in his possession any forged or counterfeit coin, stamp, currency-note or bank-note, knowing or having reason to believe the same to be forged or counterfeit and intending to use the same as genuine or that it may be used as genuine, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both. Explanation.—If a person establishes the possession of the forged or counterfeit coin, stamp, currency-note or bank-note to be from a lawful source, it shall not constitute an offence under this section.

qas.question: What is the penalty for possessing forged or counterfeit currency or government stamps under Section 180?

answers.text: The penalty is imprisonment for up to seven years, a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever makes or mends, or performs any part of the process of making or mending, or buys or sells or disposes of, or has in his possession, any machinery, die, or instrument or material for the purpose of being used, or knowing or having reason to believe that it is intended to be used, for forging or counterfeiting any coin, stamp issued by Government for the purpose of revenue, currency-note or bank-note, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for forging or counterfeiting coins, stamps, or currency notes?

answers.text: Imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What materials are mentioned as being used for forging or counterfeiting?

answers.text: Machinery, die, or instrument or material

paragraphs.context: Whoever makes, or causes to be made, or uses for any purpose whatsoever, or delivers to any person, any document purporting to be, or in any way resembling, or so nearly resembling as to be calculated to deceive, any currency-note or bank-note shall be punished with fine which may extend to three hundred rupees.

qas.question: What is the fine for making or using a document resembling a currency-note?

answers.text: Fine which may extend to three hundred rupees.

paragraphs.context: If any person, whose name appears on a document the making of which is an offence under sub-section (1), refuses, without lawful excuse, to disclose to a police officer on being so required the name and address of the person by whom it was printed or otherwise made, he shall be punished with fine which may extend to six hundred rupees.

qas.question: What is the punishment for refusing to disclose the name and address of the person who printed an offending document?

answers.text: Fine which may extend to six hundred rupees.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, fraudulently or with intent to cause loss to the Government, removes or effaces from any substance, bearing any stamp issued by Government for the purpose of revenue, any writing or document for which such stamp has been used, or removes from any writing or document a stamp which has been used for such writing or document, in order that such stamp may be used for a different writing or document, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for fraudulently removing or reusing a revenue stamp?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, fraudulently or with intent to cause loss to Government, erases or removes from a stamp issued by Government for the purpose of revenue, any mark, put or impressed upon such stamp for the purpose of denoting that the same has been used, or knowingly has in his possession or sells or disposes of any such stamp from which such mark has been erased or removed, or sells or disposes of any such stamp which he knows to have been used, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for erasing marks from used revenue stamps?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

data.title: Section 328: Mischief by Intentionally Running a Vessel Aground

paragraphs.context: Mischief Involving a Vessel: If someone intentionally runs a vessel aground or ashore with the purpose of committing theft or dishonestly misappropriating any property within the vessel, or with the intent that such theft or misappropriation may be committed, the punishment is: Imprisonment for up to 10 years, and a fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for intentionally running a vessel aground with the purpose of committing theft or misappropriation?

answers.text: The punishment for intentionally running a vessel aground with the purpose of committing theft or misappropriation is imprisonment for up to 10 years, and a fine.

data.title: Offences Related to False Information, Fraud, and Concealment of Property

paragraphs.context: Whoever, knowing or having reason to believe that an offence has been committed, gives any information respecting that offence which he knows or believes to be false, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for giving false information about an offence?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever secretes or destroys any document or electronic record which he may be lawfully compelled to produce as evidence in a Court or in any proceeding lawfully held before a public servant, as such, or obliterates or renders illegible the whole or any part of such document or electronic record with the intention of preventing the same from being produced or used as evidence before such Court or public servant as aforesaid, or after he shall have been lawfully summoned or required to produce the same for that purpose, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for secreting or destroying a document or electronic record that is lawfully required for evidence?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever falsely personates another, and in such assumed character makes any admission or statement, or confesses judgment, or causes any process to be issued or becomes bail or security, or does any other act in any suit or criminal prosecution, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for falsely personating another in a suit or criminal prosecution?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever fraudulently removes, conceals, transfers or delivers to any person any property or any interest therein, intending thereby to prevent that property or interest therein from being taken as a forfeiture or in satisfaction of a fine, under a sentence which has been pronounced, or which he knows to be likely to be pronounced, by a Court or other competent authority, or from being taken in execution of a decree or order which has been made, or which he knows to be likely to be made by a Court in a civil suit, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for fraudulently removing or concealing property to prevent it from being taken by the Court?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever fraudulently accepts, receives or claims any property or any interest therein, knowing that he has no right or rightful claim to such property or interest, or practises any deception touching any right to any property or any interest therein, intending thereby to prevent that property or interest therein from being taken as a forfeiture or in satisfaction of a fine, under a sentence which has been pronounced, or which he knows to be likely to be pronounced by a Court or other competent authority, or from being taken in execution of a decree or order which has been made, or which he knows to be likely to be made by a Court in a civil suit, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for fraudulently accepting property with no rightful claim to it?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever fraudulently causes or suffers a decree or order to be passed against him at the suit of any person for a sum not due or for a larger sum than is due to such person or for any property or interest in property to which such person is not entitled, or fraudulently causes or suffers a decree or order to be executed against him after it has been satisfied, or for anything in respect of which it has been satisfied, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for fraudulently causing a decree or order to be passed for a sum not due?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Illustration for Defamation: Example (c): A person who draws a picture of Z running away with B’s watch, intending it to be believed that Z stole B’s watch, is committing defamation unless it falls within one of the exceptions listed below.

qas.question: What is the example for defamation in this section?

answers.text: A person who draws a picture of Z running away with B’s watch, intending it to be believed that Z stole B’s watch, is committing defamation unless it falls within one of the exceptions.

paragraphs.context: Exceptions to Defamation: Exception 1 - Truth for Public Good: It is not defamation if the imputation made is true concerning a person and it is for the public good that the imputation is made or published. Note: Whether it is for the public good is a question of fact (i.e., it depends on the circumstances and evidence).

qas.question: What is the first exception to defamation?

answers.text: It is not defamation if the imputation made is true concerning a person and it is for the public good that the imputation is made or published.

paragraphs.context: Exception 2 - Opinions on Public Servants' Conduct: It is not defamation to express in good faith an opinion about a public servant’s conduct in the discharge of their public functions, or about their character as it appears in that conduct (and no further).

qas.question: What does Exception 2 state about public servants?

answers.text: It is not defamation to express in good faith an opinion about a public servant’s conduct in the discharge of their public functions, or about their character as it appears in that conduct (and no further).

paragraphs.context: Exception 3 - Opinions on Public Matters: It is not defamation to express in good faith an opinion about the conduct of any person related to a public question, and their character as it appears in that conduct (and no further). Illustration: If A expresses an opinion in good faith regarding Z's conduct in petitioning the government or participating in a public meeting, it is not defamation.

qas.question: What is Exception 3 about expressing opinions?

answers.text: It is not defamation to express in good faith an opinion about the conduct of any person related to a public question, and their character as it appears in that conduct (and no further).

paragraphs.context: Exception 4 - True Reports of Court Proceedings: It is not defamation to publish a substantially true report of the proceedings of a Court, or the result of any such proceedings. Explanation: A Magistrate or any officer holding an inquiry in open Court (preliminary to a trial) is considered a Court under this section.

qas.question: What is Exception 4 about reports of court proceedings?

answers.text: It is not defamation to publish a substantially true report of the proceedings of a Court, or the result of any such proceedings.

paragraphs.context: Exception 5 - Opinions on Merits of Court Decisions: It is not defamation to express in good faith an opinion regarding the merits of any civil or criminal case decided by a Court, or to express an opinion about the conduct of any person involved in the case (party, witness, agent), regarding their character as it appears in their conduct in the case (and no further). Illustrations: (a): A says, 'I think Z's evidence on that trial is so contradictory that he must be stupid or dishonest'—A is within this exception if said in good faith. (b): A says, 'I do not believe what Z asserted at that trial because I know him to be a man without veracity'—A is not within this exception as it reflects an opinion on Z’s general character, not just his conduct in the trial.

qas.question: What is Exception 5 about expressing opinions on court decisions?

answers.text: It is not defamation to express in good faith an opinion regarding the merits of any civil or criminal case decided by a Court, or to express an opinion about the conduct of any person involved in the case regarding their character as it appears in their conduct in the case.

paragraphs.context: Exception 6 - Opinions on Public Performances: It is not defamation to express in good faith an opinion about the merits of a public performance (such as a book, speech, or stage performance), or about the character of the performer as it appears in the performance (and no further). Explanation: A performance is considered as submitted to the public judgment either explicitly (e.g., publishing a book) or implicitly (e.g., acting in a public play). Illustrations: (a): A book published by an author is considered submitted to the public's judgment. (b): A public speech is submitted to public judgment. (c): A stage performance by an actor or singer is submitted to public judgment.

qas.question: What is Exception 6 about public performances?

answers.text: It is not defamation to express in good faith an opinion about the merits of a public performance (such as a book, speech, or stage performance), or about the character of the performer as it appears in the performance.

data.title: Theft with Preparation for Harm and Extortion

paragraphs.context: Whoever commits theft, having made preparation for causing death, or hurt, or restraint, or fear of death, or of hurt, or of restraint, to any person, in order to the committing of such theft, or in order to the effecting of his escape after the committing of such theft, or in order to the retaining of property taken by such theft, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for theft involving preparation for harm or fear?

answers.text: Rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever intentionally puts any person in fear of any injury to that person, or to any other, and thereby dishonestly induces the person so put in fear to deliver to any person any property, or valuable security or anything signed or sealed which may be converted into a valuable security, commits extortion.

qas.question: What constitutes extortion?

answers.text: Intentionally putting any person in fear of injury and dishonestly inducing them to deliver property, security, or anything signed or sealed.

paragraphs.context: Explanation 1: The offense doesn't require the intent to cause damage to the property owner specifically. It suffices if the action causes wrongful loss or damage to any person, even if the property does not belong to that person.

qas.question: Does the offense of mischief require the intent to cause damage to the property owner?

answers.text: No, the offense of mischief doesn't require the intent to cause damage to the property owner specifically. It suffices if the action causes wrongful loss or damage to any person.

data.title: Indian Penal Code - Trafficking, Exploitation, and Unlawful Labour

paragraphs.context: (f) by inducement, including the giving or receiving of payments or benefits, in order to achieve the consent of any person having control over the person recruited, transported, harboured, transferred or received, commits the offence of trafficking. Explanation 1.—The expression “exploitation” shall include any act of physical exploitation or any form of sexual exploitation, slavery or practices similar to slavery, servitude, beggary or forced removal of organs. Explanation 2.—The consent of the victim is immaterial in determination of the offence of trafficking.

qas.question: What is included in the definition of 'exploitation' under Section 143?

answers.text: Exploitation includes physical exploitation, sexual exploitation, slavery, servitude, beggary, or forced removal of organs.

qas.question: Is the consent of the victim relevant in determining the offence of trafficking under Section 143?

answers.text: No, the consent of the victim is immaterial in determining the offence of trafficking.

paragraphs.context: 2) Whoever commits the offence of trafficking shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than seven years, but which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for trafficking under Section 143(2)?

answers.text: The punishment is rigorous imprisonment for 7 to 10 years, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: 3) Where the offence involves the trafficking of more than one person, it shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than ten years but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment when the offence involves trafficking of more than one person under Section 143(3)?

answers.text: The punishment is rigorous imprisonment for 10 years to life imprisonment, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: 4) Where the offence involves the trafficking of a child, it shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than ten years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment when the offence involves trafficking of a child under Section 143(4)?

answers.text: The punishment is rigorous imprisonment for 10 years to life imprisonment, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: 5) Where the offence involves the trafficking of more than one child, it shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than fourteen years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment when the offence involves trafficking of more than one child under Section 143(5)?

answers.text: The punishment is rigorous imprisonment for 14 years to life imprisonment, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: 6) If a person is convicted of the offence of trafficking of a child on more than one occasion, then such person shall be punished with imprisonment for life, which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person’s natural life, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for repeat offenders convicted of trafficking a child under Section 143(6)?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment for life, which means imprisonment for the remainder of the person's natural life, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: 7) When a public servant or a police officer is involved in the trafficking of any person then, such public servant or police officer shall be punished with imprisonment for life, which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person’s natural life, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for a public servant or police officer involved in trafficking under Section 143(7)?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment for life, which means imprisonment for the remainder of the person's natural life, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: 144. (1) Whoever, knowingly or having reason to believe that a child has been trafficked, engages such child for sexual exploitation in any manner, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than five years, but which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for engaging a trafficked child for sexual exploitation under Section 144(1)?

answers.text: The punishment is rigorous imprisonment for 5 to 10 years, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: 2) Whoever, knowingly or having reason to believe that a person has been trafficked, engages such person for sexual exploitation in any manner, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than three years, but which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for engaging a trafficked person for sexual exploitation under Section 144(2)?

answers.text: The punishment is rigorous imprisonment for 3 to 7 years, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: 145. Whoever habitually imports, exports, removes, buys, sells, traffics or deals in slaves, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term not exceeding ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for dealing in slaves under Section 145?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment for life or imprisonment for up to 10 years, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: 146. Whoever unlawfully compels any person to labour against the will of that person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for unlawfully compelling a person to labour under Section 146?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment for up to one year, or a fine, or both.

data.title: False Evidence and Offences Against Public Justice

paragraphs.context: Whoever, being legally bound by an oath or by an express provision of law to state the truth, or being bound by law to make a declaration upon any subject, makes any statement which is false, and which he either knows or believes to be false or does not believe to be true, is said to give false evidence. Explanation 1.—A statement is within the meaning of this section, whether it is made verbally or otherwise. Explanation 2.—A false statement as to the belief of the person attesting is within the meaning of this section, and a person may be guilty of giving false evidence by stating that he believes a thing which he does not believe, as well as by stating that he knows a thing which he does not know.

qas.question: What constitutes giving false evidence under this law?

answers.text: Making any statement which is false, and which the person either knows or believes to be false or does not believe to be true.

qas.question: Can a false verbal statement be considered false evidence?

answers.text: A statement is within the meaning of this section, whether it is made verbally or otherwise.

paragraphs.context: Whoever causes any circumstance to exist or makes any false entry in any book or record, or electronic record or makes any document or electronic record containing a false statement, intending that such circumstance, false entry or false statement may appear in evidence in a judicial proceeding, or in a proceeding taken by law before a public servant as such, or before an arbitrator, and that such circumstance, false entry or false statement, so appearing in evidence, may cause any person who in such proceeding is to form an opinion upon the evidence, to entertain an erroneous opinion touching any point material to the result of such proceeding is said to fabricate false evidence.

qas.question: What is the definition of fabricating false evidence?

answers.text: Causing any circumstance to exist or making any false entry in any book, record, or electronic record, or making any document or electronic record containing a false statement, intending that it may appear in evidence and cause an erroneous opinion in a judicial proceeding.

qas.question: Can false entries in electronic records be considered as fabricating false evidence?

answers.text: Yes, making any false entry in an electronic record with the intention that it may appear in evidence is considered fabricating false evidence.

paragraphs.context: Illustrations: (a) A puts jewels into a box belonging to Z, with the intention that they may be found in that box, and that this circumstance may cause Z to be convicted of theft. A has fabricated false evidence. (b) A makes a false entry in his shop-book for the purpose of using it as corroborative evidence in a Court. A has fabricated false evidence. (c) A, with the intention of causing Z to be convicted of a criminal conspiracy, writes a letter in imitation of Z's handwriting, purporting to be addressed to an accomplice in such criminal conspiracy, and puts the letter in a place which he knows that the officers of the police are likely to search. A has fabricated false evidence.

qas.question: What is an example of fabricating false evidence involving a false entry in a shop-book?

answers.text: A makes a false entry in his shop-book for the purpose of using it as corroborative evidence in a Court.

qas.question: How does fabricating a letter in imitation of handwriting qualify as false evidence?

answers.text: Writing a letter in imitation of Z's handwriting, purporting to be addressed to an accomplice, and placing it where police are likely to search.

paragraphs.context: Cheating with Knowledge of Wrongful Loss: If a person cheats, knowing that it will likely cause a wrongful loss to someone whose interests they are legally obligated to protect, the punishment increases to imprisonment for up to 5 years, a fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for cheating with knowledge of wrongful loss?

answers.text: The punishment for cheating with knowledge of wrongful loss is imprisonment for up to 5 years, a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: An assembly of five or more persons is designated an 'unlawful assembly', if the common object of the persons composing that assembly is— (a) to overawe by criminal force, or show of criminal force, the Central Government or any State Government or Parliament or the Legislature of any State, or any public servant in the exercise of the lawful power of such public servant; or (b) to resist the execution of any law, or of any legal process; or (c) to commit any mischief or criminal trespass, or other offence; or (d) by means of criminal force, or show of criminal force, to any person, to take or obtain possession of any property, or to deprive any person of the enjoyment of a right of way, or of the use of water or other incorporeal right of which he is in possession or enjoyment, or to enforce any right or supposed right; or (e) by means of criminal force, or show of criminal force, to compel any person to do what he is not legally bound to do, or to omit to do what he is legally entitled to do.

qas.question: What is the minimum number of persons required to form an unlawful assembly?

answers.text: Five

qas.question: What are the actions that make an assembly unlawful?

answers.text: (a) to overawe by criminal force, or show of criminal force, the Central Government or any State Government or Parliament or the Legislature of any State, or any public servant in the exercise of the lawful power of such public servant; or (b) to resist the execution of any law, or of any legal process; or (c) to commit any mischief or criminal trespass, or other offence; or (d) by means of criminal force, or show of criminal force, to any person, to take or obtain possession of any property, or to deprive any person of the enjoyment of a right of way, or of the use of water or other incorporeal right of which he is in possession or enjoyment, or to enforce any right or supposed right; or (e) by means of criminal force, or show of criminal force, to compel any person to do what he is not legally bound to do, or to omit to do what he is legally entitled to do.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, being aware of facts which render any assembly an unlawful assembly, intentionally joins that assembly, or continues in it, is said to be a member of an unlawful assembly and such member shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for being a member of an unlawful assembly?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, being armed with any deadly weapon, or with anything which, used as a weapon of offence, is likely to cause death, is a member of an unlawful assembly, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for being armed as a member of an unlawful assembly?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever hires or engages, or employs, or promotes, or connives at the hiring, engagement or employment of any person to join or become a member of any unlawful assembly, shall be punishable as a member of such unlawful assembly, and for any offence which may be committed by any such person as a member of such unlawful assembly in pursuance of such hiring, engagement or employment, in the same manner as if he had been a member of such unlawful assembly, or himself had committed such offence.

qas.question: What is the punishment for hiring or promoting someone to join an unlawful assembly?

answers.text: Punishable as a member of such unlawful assembly, and for any offence which may be committed by any such person as a member of such unlawful assembly.

paragraphs.context: Definition of Cheating: A person is said to cheat when they deceive another person by fraudulently or dishonestly inducing them to: Deliver property to someone, Consent to someone retaining property, Do or omit something they wouldn’t normally do or omit, resulting in harm to their body, mind, reputation, or property.

qas.question: What is the definition of cheating under Section 318?

answers.text: Cheating occurs when someone deceives another person by fraudulently or dishonestly inducing them to deliver property, consent to retaining property, or do something they wouldn’t normally do, resulting in harm.

paragraphs.context: Explanation: A dishonest concealment of facts also constitutes deception under this section.

qas.question: What does the explanation of Section 318 indicate about dishonest concealment of facts?

answers.text: The explanation of Section 318 indicates that a dishonest concealment of facts is also considered deception under this section.

paragraphs.context: Illustrations: Example 1: A pretends to be in the Civil Service and deceives Z, leading Z to give him goods on credit without intending to pay for them. A cheats.

qas.question: Give an example of someone cheating under Section 318.

answers.text: An example of someone cheating under Section 318 is when A pretends to be in the Civil Service and deceives Z into giving him goods on credit without intending to pay for them.

paragraphs.context: Example 2: A puts a counterfeit mark on an article, misleading Z into thinking it is made by a famous manufacturer, thus causing Z to buy it. A cheats.

qas.question: What is another example of cheating under Section 318?

answers.text: Another example of cheating is when A puts a counterfeit mark on an article, misleading Z into thinking it is made by a famous manufacturer, thus causing Z to buy it.

paragraphs.context: Example 3: A shows a false sample of an article to Z, deceiving Z into believing the actual article matches the sample, leading to Z buying it. A cheats.

qas.question: What is another example of cheating under Section 318?

answers.text: Another example of cheating is when A shows a false sample of an article to Z, deceiving Z into believing the actual article matches the sample, leading to Z buying it.

paragraphs.context: Example 4: A uses a dishonored bill to buy an article, intending not to pay for it. A cheats.

qas.question: Give an example of cheating related to dishonored bills under Section 318.

answers.text: An example of cheating related to dishonored bills is when A uses a dishonored bill to buy an article, intending not to pay for it.

paragraphs.context: Example 5: A pledges non-diamonds as diamonds to Z, inducing Z to lend money based on the false representation. A cheats.

qas.question: What is an example of cheating involving false representation of diamonds under Section 318?

answers.text: An example of cheating involving false representation of diamonds is when A pledges non-diamonds as diamonds to Z, inducing Z to lend money based on the false representation.

paragraphs.context: Example 6: A deceives Z into believing they will repay a loan, but A does not intend to repay. A cheats.

qas.question: What is an example of cheating involving a loan under Section 318?

answers.text: An example of cheating involving a loan is when A deceives Z into believing they will repay a loan, but A does not intend to repay.

paragraphs.context: Example 7: A deceives Z into thinking they will deliver a certain amount of indigo plant, inducing Z to lend money, even though A has no intention of delivering. A cheats.

qas.question: What is an example of cheating involving indigo plants under Section 318?

answers.text: An example of cheating involving indigo plants is when A deceives Z into thinking they will deliver a certain amount of indigo plant, inducing Z to lend money, even though A has no intention of delivering.

paragraphs.context: Example 8: A deceives Z into thinking they have fulfilled their part of a contract, and thus induces Z to pay money. A cheats.

qas.question: What is an example of cheating involving a contract under Section 318?

answers.text: An example of cheating involving a contract is when A deceives Z into thinking they have fulfilled their part of the contract, inducing Z to pay money.

paragraphs.context: Mischief by Affecting Water Supply: Whoever causes or is likely to cause a reduction in the supply of water for agriculture, food, drink, or cleanliness, will face imprisonment for up to 5 years, a fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for mischief by affecting water supply?

answers.text: The punishment for mischief by affecting water supply is imprisonment for up to 5 years, a fine, or both.

data.title: Legal Offenses Relating to Public Servants

paragraphs.context: Whoever, knowing that, by an order promulgated by a public servant lawfully empowered to promulgate such order, he is directed to abstain from a certain act, or to take certain order with certain property in his possession or under his management, disobeys such direction,–– (a) shall, if such disobedience causes or tends to cause obstruction, annoyance or injury, or risk of obstruction, annoyance or injury, to any person lawfully employed, be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to two thousand and five hundred rupees, or with both; (b) and where such disobedience causes or tends to cause danger to human life, health or safety, or causes or tends to cause a riot or affray, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for disobeying a public servant's lawful order causing annoyance or obstruction?

answers.text: Simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to two thousand and five hundred rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for disobedience leading to danger to human life or causing a riot?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever holds out any threat of injury to any public servant, or to any person in whom he believes that public servant to be interested, for the purpose of inducing that public servant to do any act, or to forbear or delay to do any act, connected with the exercise of the public functions of such public servant, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for threatening a public servant to influence their actions?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever holds out any threat of injury to any person for the purpose of inducing that person to refrain or desist from making a legal application for protection against any injury to any public servant legally empowered as such to give such protection, or to cause such protection to be given, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for threatening someone to prevent them from seeking protection for a public servant?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever attempts to commit suicide with the intent to compel or restrain any public servant from discharging his official duty shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both, or with community service.

qas.question: What is the punishment for attempting suicide to influence a public servant's duties?

answers.text: Simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both, or with community service.

paragraphs.context: A takes Z’s article without consent, intending to return it only if Z pays a reward. Since A acts dishonestly, he commits theft.

qas.question: Why does A commit theft if he takes Z’s article without consent and intends to return it only if Z pays a reward?

answers.text: Because A acts dishonestly by conditioning the return of Z’s property on a reward.

paragraphs.context: A, being friendly with Z, borrows a book from Z’s library in his absence, intending to return it. If A believed Z’s implied consent, he has not committed theft.

qas.question: Why does A not commit theft if he borrows a book from Z’s library, believing in Z’s implied consent?

answers.text: Because A believed in Z’s implied consent, he did not act dishonestly.

paragraphs.context: (3) Whoever wrongfully confines any person for three days, or more, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees, or with both. (4) Whoever wrongfully confines any person for ten days or more, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, and shall also be liable to fine which shall not be less than ten thousand rupees. (5) Whoever keeps any person in wrongful confinement, knowing that a writ for the liberation of that person has been duly issued, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years in addition to any term of imprisonment to which he may be liable under any other section of this Chapter and shall also be liable to fine. (6) Whoever wrongfully confines any person in such manner as to indicate an intention that the confinement of such person may not be known to any person interested in the person so confined, or to any public servant, or that the place of such confinement may not be known to or discovered by any such person or public servant as hereinbefore mentioned, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years in addition to any other punishment to which he may be liable for such wrongful confinement and shall also be liable to fine. (7) Whoever wrongfully confines any person for the purpose of extorting from the person confined, or from any person interested in the person confined, any property or valuable security or of constraining the person confined or any person interested in such person to do anything illegal or to give any information which may facilitate the commission of an offence, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine. (8) Whoever wrongfully confines any person for the purpose of extorting from the person confined or any person interested in the person confined any confession or any information which may lead to the detection of an offence or misconduct, or for the purpose of constraining the person confined or any person interested in the person confined to restore or to cause the restoration of any property or valuable security or to satisfy any claim or demand, or to give information which may lead to the restoration of any property or valuable security, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for wrongful confinement of a person for three days or more under Section 127?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for wrongful confinement of a person for ten days or more under Section 127?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, and shall also be liable to fine which shall not be less than ten thousand rupees.

qas.question: What is the punishment for wrongful confinement when a writ for the person's liberation has been issued under Section 127?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years in addition to any term of imprisonment to which the person may be liable under any other section, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for wrongful confinement where the intention is to prevent discovery by interested parties or public servants under Section 127?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years in addition to any other punishment, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for wrongful confinement for extorting property or valuable security under Section 127?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for wrongful confinement for extorting a confession or information under Section 127?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.

data.title: Explanation and Punishments for Lurking House-Trespass and Housebreaking

paragraphs.context: Explanation on House-Trespass and Housebreaking: Out-Houses and Internal Communication: Any out-house or building connected to a house, with immediate internal communication between them, is considered part of the house within the meaning of house-trespass and housebreaking.

qas.question: What is considered part of the house in terms of house-trespass and housebreaking?

answers.text: Any out-house or building connected to a house, with immediate internal communication between them, is considered part of the house within the meaning of house-trespass and housebreaking.

paragraphs.context: Illustrations of House-Trespass and Housebreaking: Example Scenarios: (a) A makes a hole in the wall of Z’s house and puts his hand through. This constitutes house-breaking. (b) A creeps into a ship at a port-hole between decks. This is house-breaking. (c) A enters Z’s house through a window. This is house-breaking. (d) A enters Z’s house by opening a fastened door. This is house-breaking. (e) A lifts a latch with a wire through a hole to open the door and enters Z’s house. This is house-breaking. (f) A finds the key to Z’s house and enters by using that key. This is house-breaking. (g) A knocks Z down and forces a passage into Z’s house. This is house-breaking. (h) A enters Z’s house after threatening to beat Z, the door-keeper. This is house-breaking.

qas.question: Which of the following constitutes house-breaking? (a) A makes a hole in the wall of Z’s house and puts his hand through.

answers.text: This constitutes house-breaking.

qas.question: Which of the following constitutes house-breaking? (b) A creeps into a ship at a port-hole between decks.

answers.text: This is house-breaking.

qas.question: Which of the following constitutes house-breaking? (c) A enters Z’s house through a window.

answers.text: This is house-breaking.

qas.question: Which of the following constitutes house-breaking? (d) A enters Z’s house by opening a fastened door.

answers.text: This is house-breaking.

qas.question: Which of the following constitutes house-breaking? (e) A lifts a latch with a wire through a hole to open the door and enters Z’s house.

answers.text: This is house-breaking.

qas.question: Which of the following constitutes house-breaking? (f) A finds the key to Z’s house and enters by using that key.

answers.text: This is house-breaking.

qas.question: Which of the following constitutes house-breaking? (g) A knocks Z down and forces a passage into Z’s house.

answers.text: This is house-breaking.

qas.question: Which of the following constitutes house-breaking? (h) A enters Z’s house after threatening to beat Z, the door-keeper.

answers.text: This is house-breaking.

paragraphs.context: Punishments for Lurking House-Trespass and Housebreaking: General Punishment: Anyone committing lurking house-trespass or housebreaking can be punished with: Imprisonment for up to 2 years, and also liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the general punishment for lurking house-trespass or housebreaking?

answers.text: Anyone committing lurking house-trespass or housebreaking can be punished with imprisonment for up to 2 years, and also liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Punishment after Sunset and Before Sunrise: If the lurking house-trespass or housebreaking occurs after sunset and before sunrise, the punishment is: Imprisonment for up to 3 years, and also liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment if lurking house-trespass or housebreaking occurs after sunset and before sunrise?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment for up to 3 years, and also liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Punishment for Commission with Intent to Commit Another Offense: If the house-trespass or housebreaking is committed with the intent to commit another offense punishable with imprisonment: Imprisonment for up to 3 years, and also liable to fine. If the intended offense is theft, the imprisonment term can be extended to 10 years.

qas.question: What is the punishment if house-trespass or housebreaking is committed with the intent to commit theft?

answers.text: If the intended offense is theft, the imprisonment term can be extended to 10 years.

paragraphs.context: Punishment after Sunset and Before Sunrise (Intent to Commit an Offense): If the offense occurs after sunset and before sunrise, and is committed to facilitate another offense punishable with imprisonment: Imprisonment for up to 5 years, and also liable to fine. If the intended offense is theft, the term of imprisonment may extend to 14 years.

qas.question: What is the punishment if the offense occurs after sunset and before sunrise, and is committed to facilitate theft?

answers.text: The term of imprisonment may extend to 14 years if the intended offense is theft.

paragraphs.context: Punishment for Preparedness to Cause Hurt or Assault: If the house-trespass or housebreaking is committed with preparation to cause hurt, assault, wrongful restraint, or to instill fear of hurt, the punishment can be: Imprisonment for up to 10 years, and also liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment if house-trespass or housebreaking is committed with preparation to cause hurt or assault?

answers.text: The punishment can be imprisonment for up to 10 years, and also liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Punishment after Sunset and Before Sunrise (Preparedness for Hurt or Assault): If the house-trespass or housebreaking occurs after sunset and before sunrise, with preparation for causing hurt, assault, or wrongful restraint, the punishment is: Imprisonment for up to 14 years, and also liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for house-trespass or housebreaking after sunset and before sunrise, with preparation for causing hurt or assault?

answers.text: The punishment is imprisonment for up to 14 years, and also liable to fine.

data.title: False Evidence and Offences Against Public Justice

paragraphs.context: Whoever intentionally gives false evidence in any stage of a judicial proceeding, or fabricates false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of a judicial proceeding, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees. Whoever intentionally gives or fabricates false evidence in any case other than that referred to in sub-section (1), shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine which may extend to five thousand rupees. Explanation 1.—A trial before a Court-martial is a judicial proceeding. Explanation 2.—An investigation directed by law preliminary to a proceeding before a Court, is a stage of a judicial proceeding, though that investigation may not take place before a Court. Explanation 3.—An investigation directed by a Court according to law, and conducted under the authority of a Court, is a stage of a judicial proceeding, though that investigation may not take place before a Court.

qas.question: What is the punishment for giving false evidence in a judicial proceeding?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and fine up to ten thousand rupees.

qas.question: Does a trial before a Court-martial count as a judicial proceeding?

answers.text: A trial before a Court-martial is a judicial proceeding.

qas.question: What is the punishment for fabricating false evidence in cases not related to judicial proceedings?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and fine up to five thousand rupees.

paragraphs.context: Whoever gives or fabricates false evidence, intending thereby to cause, or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby cause, any person to be convicted of an offence which is capital by the law for the time being in force in India shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine which may extend to fifty thousand rupees. If an innocent person be convicted and executed in consequence of false evidence referred to in sub-section (1), the person who gives such false evidence shall be punished either with death or the punishment specified in sub-section (1).

qas.question: What is the punishment for giving false evidence leading to a conviction in a capital offence?

answers.text: Imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and fine up to fifty thousand rupees.

qas.question: What is the punishment if an innocent person is executed due to false evidence?

answers.text: The person who gives such false evidence shall be punished either with death or the punishment specified in sub-section (1).

paragraphs.context: Whoever gives or fabricates false evidence intending thereby to cause, or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby cause, any person to be convicted of an offence which by the law for the time being in force in India is not capital, but punishable with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment for a term of seven years or upwards, shall be punished as a person convicted of that offence would be liable to be punished. Illustration: A gives false evidence before a Court, intending thereby to cause Z to be convicted of a dacoity. The punishment of dacoity is imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, with or without fine. A, therefore, is liable to imprisonment for life or imprisonment, with or without fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for giving false evidence in non-capital offences?

answers.text: The person shall be punished as a person convicted of that offence would be liable to be punished.

qas.question: What is the punishment for dacoity in India?

answers.text: Imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, with or without fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever threatens another with any injury to his person, reputation or property or to the person or reputation of any one in whom that person is interested, with intent to cause that person to give false evidence shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both. If an innocent person is convicted and sentenced in consequence of false evidence referred to in sub-section (1), with death or imprisonment for more than seven years, the person who threatens shall be punished with the same punishment and sentence in the same manner and to the same extent such innocent person is punished and sentenced.

qas.question: What is the punishment for threatening someone to give false evidence?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What happens if an innocent person is sentenced to death due to false evidence provided under threat?

answers.text: The person who threatens shall be punished with the same punishment and sentence in the same manner and to the same extent such innocent person is punished and sentenced.

data.title: Offences Related to Acceptance and Concealment of Offences

paragraphs.context: Whoever accepts or attempts to obtain, or agrees to accept, any gratification for himself or any other person, or any restitution of property to himself or any other person, in consideration of his concealing an offence or of his screening any person from legal punishment for any offence, or of his not proceeding against any person for the purpose of bringing him to legal punishment shall,— (a) if the offence is punishable with death, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine; (b) if the offence is punishable with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment which may extend to ten years, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine; (c) if the offence is punishable with imprisonment not extending to ten years, be punished with imprisonment of the description provided for the offence for a term which may extend to one-fourth part of the longest term of imprisonment provided for the offence, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for accepting gratification to conceal an offence or screen a person from legal punishment?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever gives or causes, or offers or agrees to give or cause, any gratification to any person, or restores or causes the restoration of any property to any person, in consideration of that person’s concealing an offence, or of his screening any person from legal punishment for any offence, or of his not proceeding against any person for the purpose of bringing him to legal punishment shall,— (a) if the offence is punishable with death, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine; (b) if the offence is punishable with imprisonment for life or with imprisonment which may extend to ten years, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine; (c) if the offence is punishable with imprisonment not extending to ten years, be punished with imprisonment of the description provided for the offence for a term which may extend to one-fourth part of the longest term of imprisonment provided for the offence, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for giving gratification to conceal an offence or screen a person from legal punishment?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: The provisions of this section and section 250 do not extend to any case in which the offence may lawfully be compounded.

qas.question: Is there any exception to the provisions of Sections 250 and 251?

answers.text: Yes, the provisions of this section and section 250 do not extend to any case in which the offence may lawfully be compounded.

paragraphs.context: Whoever takes or agrees or consents to take any gratification under pretence or on account of helping any person to recover any movable property of which he shall have been deprived by any offence punishable under this Sanhita, shall, unless he uses all means in his power to cause the offender to be apprehended and convicted of the offence, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for taking gratification for helping someone recover movable property?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Chapter XIX - Criminal Intimidation, Insult, Annoyance, Defamation, etc. Section 351 - Criminal Intimidation. Criminal Intimidation: Threatening another person (or their interests) with injury to their person, reputation, or property (or to someone they care about), with the intent to: Cause alarm or fear in that person, or Compel them to do or omit an act that they are legally bound to do or entitled to do, This constitutes criminal intimidation.

qas.question: What constitutes criminal intimidation?

answers.text: Threatening another person (or their interests) with injury to their person, reputation, or property, with the intent to cause alarm or fear or compel them to do or omit an act they are legally bound to do.

paragraphs.context: Section 351 - Explanation and Punishments for Criminal Intimidation. Threats Involving a Deceased Person's Reputation: Threatening to harm the reputation of a deceased person in whom the person threatened has an interest falls under this section. Criminal Intimidation by Threatening Harm: General Threat: A person who threatens another (with intent to cause alarm or coerce action) is punishable with: Imprisonment for up to two years, or fine, or both. Criminal Intimidation with Serious Threats: Serious threats involving: Death, grievous hurt, destruction by fire, or offenses punishable with life imprisonment or death, or Imputing unchastity to a woman, shall be punishable by: Imprisonment for up to seven years, or fine, or both. Criminal Intimidation by Anonymous Threat: Anonymous threats or threats made while concealing the identity of the threatener shall carry an additional punishment of: Imprisonment for up to two years, along with any other punishment applicable to the offense under section (1).

qas.question: What is the punishment for general criminal intimidation?

answers.text: Imprisonment for up to two years, or fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: Section 352 - Provocation Leading to Public Disorder. Intentionally Insulting and Provoking: Insulting a person to provoke them into breaking public peace or committing an offense: Imprisonment for up to two years, or fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for insulting someone to provoke public disorder?

answers.text: Imprisonment for up to two years, or fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: Section 353 - False Statements, Rumors, and Reports. False Statements Leading to Mutiny or Misconduct: Making or circulating false statements or rumors with the intent to: Induce mutiny or cause soldiers, sailors, or airmen to fail in their duties, or Create fear or alarm that could lead to a crime, or Incite violence between communities, is punishable by: Imprisonment for up to three years, or fine, or both. Inciting Hatred or Ill-Will Through False Information: Making or circulating false statements that promote enmity or hatred between different communities or groups (based on religion, race, language, etc.) is punishable by: Imprisonment for up to three years, or fine, or both. Offense Committed in a Place of Worship: If the offense under sub-section (2) is committed in a place of worship or during religious ceremonies, the punishment is: Imprisonment for up to five years, and fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for making false statements that lead to mutiny or misconduct?

answers.text: Imprisonment for up to three years, or fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: Section 353 - Exception for False Statements. Exception for Good Faith: A person making, publishing, or circulating a false statement, information, rumor, or report will not be considered an offense if they had reasonable grounds to believe the statement was true and acted in good faith without any intent to cause harm or incite fear.

qas.question: What is the exception for making false statements under Section 353?

answers.text: A person will not be considered an offense if they had reasonable grounds to believe the statement was true and acted in good faith without any intent to cause harm or incite fear.

paragraphs.context: Section 354 - Inducing Belief in Divine Displeasure. Inducing Belief in Divine Displeasure: Whoever causes or attempts to cause someone to do something, or not to do something, by inducing them to believe that their actions (or omissions) will incur Divine displeasure will be punished with: Imprisonment for up to one year, or fine, or both. Illustrations: Example 1: A person sits outside someone's door (dharnas) with the intention of causing the other person to believe that their inaction would lead to Divine displeasure. Example 2: A person threatens harm to their own child, suggesting that the harm will lead to Divine displeasure for the person who does not act according to their wishes.

qas.question: What is the punishment for inducing belief in Divine displeasure?

answers.text: Imprisonment for up to one year, or fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: Section 355 - Intoxication and Annoyance in Public Places. Public Intoxication and Annoyance: Intoxicated individuals causing annoyance in public places or trespassing areas they are not permitted to enter shall be punished with: Simple imprisonment for up to 24 hours, or fine up to ₹1,000, or both, or community service.

qas.question: What is the punishment for public intoxication and annoyance?

answers.text: Simple imprisonment for up to 24 hours, or fine up to ₹1,000, or both, or community service.

paragraphs.context: Section 356 - Defamation. Definition of Defamation: Defamation occurs when someone makes or publishes words (spoken, written, or visual) that impute something negative to a person's reputation, intending to harm it or knowing that it will harm the person's reputation. Examples and Explanations: Imputation about a Deceased Person: If an imputation made about a deceased person would harm their reputation if they were alive, and the intention is to harm their family's feelings, it is considered defamation. Imputation about a Group or Association: A defamatory imputation can be made about a company, association, or collective group. Imputation in the Form of an Irony: An imputation expressed ironically or as an alternative may still be defamatory. What Constitutes Harmful Reputation: An imputation is considered defamatory if it lowers the moral or intellectual character of the person, damages their caste or occupation, or affects their credit or reputation. Example: Example 1: Saying 'Z is an honest man; he never stole B's watch' while implying that Z actually stole the watch is defamation. Example 2: Pointing to Z when asked who stole the watch, with the intent to make others believe that Z did it, is defamation.

qas.question: What is the definition of defamation?

answers.text: Defamation occurs when someone makes or publishes words (spoken, written, or visual) that impute something negative to a person's reputation, intending to harm it or knowing that it will harm the person's reputation.

data.title: Indian Penal Code - Punishment for Assault or Criminal Force

paragraphs.context: 131. Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person otherwise than on grave and sudden provocation given by that person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both. Explanation 1.—Grave and sudden provocation will not mitigate the punishment for an offence under this section,— (a) if the provocation is sought or voluntarily provoked by the offender as an excuse for the offence; or (b) if the provocation is given by anything done in obedience to the law, or by a public servant, in the lawful exercise of the powers of such public servant; or (c) if the provocation is given by anything done in the lawful exercise of the right of private defence. Explanation 2.—Whether the provocation was grave and sudden enough to mitigate the offence, is a question of fact.

qas.question: What is the punishment for assault or criminal force without grave provocation under Section 131?

answers.text: The punishment can be imprisonment for up to three months, a fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.

qas.question: What conditions prevent grave provocation from mitigating the punishment under Section 131?

answers.text: Grave provocation will not mitigate the punishment if the provocation is sought by the offender, done in obedience to the law, or done in the lawful exercise of private defence.

paragraphs.context: 132. Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person being a public servant in the execution of his duty as such public servant, or with intent to prevent or deter that person from discharging his duty as such public servant, or in consequence of anything done or attempted to be done by such person in the lawful discharge of his duty as such public servant, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for assaulting a public servant in the execution of their duty under Section 132?

answers.text: The punishment can be imprisonment for up to two years, a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: 133. Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person, intending thereby to dishonour that person, otherwise than on grave and sudden provocation given by that person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for assault with the intent to dishonour a person under Section 133?

answers.text: The punishment can be imprisonment for up to two years, a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: 134. Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person, in attempting to commit theft on any property which that person is then wearing or carrying, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for assault in an attempt to commit theft under Section 134?

answers.text: The punishment can be imprisonment for up to two years, a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: 135. Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person, in attempting wrongfully to confine that person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for assault in an attempt to wrongfully confine someone under Section 135?

answers.text: The punishment can be imprisonment for up to one year, a fine up to five thousand rupees, or both.

data.title: Indian Penal Code - Voluntarily Causing Grievous Hurt by Acid or Harmful Substances

paragraphs.context: Provided further that any fine imposed under this sub-section shall be paid to the victim. (2) Whoever throws or attempts to throw acid on any person or attempts to administer acid to any person, or attempts to use any other means, with the intention of causing permanent or partial damage or deformity or burns or maiming or disfigurement or disability or grievous hurt to that person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than five years but which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine. Explanation 1.—For the purposes of this section, 'acid' includes any substance which has acidic or corrosive character or burning nature, that is capable of causing bodily injury leading to scars or disfigurement or temporary or permanent disability. Explanation 2.—For the purposes of this section, permanent or partial damage or deformity or permanent vegetative state shall not be required to be irreversible.

qas.question: What is the punishment for throwing or attempting to throw acid on any person under Section 124?

answers.text: The person shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than five years but which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What does the term 'acid' include under Section 124?

answers.text: 'Acid' includes any substance which has acidic or corrosive character or burning nature, capable of causing bodily injury leading to scars or disfigurement or temporary or permanent disability.

qas.question: Is permanent or partial damage or deformity required to be irreversible under Section 124?

answers.text: No, permanent or partial damage or deformity or permanent vegetative state is not required to be irreversible under Section 124.

paragraphs.context: Mischief by Destroying Places of Worship or Dwelling: If fire or explosives are used to destroy buildings like places of worship, human dwellings, or places for storing property, the punishment is: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment for up to 10 years, and a fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for destroying places of worship or dwelling using fire or explosives?

answers.text: The punishment for destroying places of worship or dwelling using fire or explosives is imprisonment for life, or imprisonment for up to 10 years, and a fine.

paragraphs.context: Illustrations: (a) A writing expressing the terms of a contract, which may be used as evidence of the contract, is a document. (b) A cheque upon a banker is a document. (c) A power-of-attorney is a document. (d) A map or plan which is intended to be used or which may be used as evidence, is a document. (e) A writing containing directions or instructions is a document.

qas.question: What is an example of a document as per illustration (a)?

answers.text: A writing expressing the terms of a contract, which may be used as evidence of the contract.

qas.question: What example of a document is provided in illustration (b)?

answers.text: A cheque upon a banker is a document.

qas.question: What example of a document is mentioned in illustration (c)?

answers.text: A power-of-attorney is a document.

qas.question: How is a map or plan considered a document according to illustration (d)?

answers.text: A map or plan which is intended to be used or which may be used as evidence.

qas.question: What kind of writing is classified as a document under illustration (e)?

answers.text: A writing containing directions or instructions.

paragraphs.context: Explanation 2.—Whatever is expressed by means of letters, figures or marks as explained by mercantile or other usage, shall be deemed to be expressed by such letters, figures or marks within the meaning of this section, although the same may not be actually expressed. Illustration: A writes his name on the back of a bill of exchange payable to his order. The meaning of the endorsement, as explained by mercantile usage, is that the bill is to be paid to the holder. The endorsement is a document, and shall be construed in the same manner as if the words 'pay to the holder' or words to that effect had been written over the signature;

qas.question: What does Explanation 2 state about the expression of letters, figures, or marks?

answers.text: Whatever is expressed by means of letters, figures or marks as explained by mercantile or other usage shall be deemed to be expressed by such letters, figures or marks within the meaning of this section, although the same may not be actually expressed.

qas.question: What example is provided for the interpretation of mercantile usage?

answers.text: A writes his name on the back of a bill of exchange payable to his order. The meaning of the endorsement, as explained by mercantile usage, is that the bill is to be paid to the holder.

paragraphs.context: Fraudulently means doing anything with the intention to defraud but not otherwise. Gender: The pronoun 'he' and its derivatives are used of any person, whether male, female or transgender. paragraphs.context: Good faith: Nothing is said to be done or believed in 'good faith' which is done or believed without due care and attention. Government means the Central Government or a State Government.

paragraphs.context: Harbour includes supplying a person with shelter, food, drink, money, clothes, arms, ammunition or means of conveyance, or the assisting a person by any means, whether of the same kind as those enumerated in this clause or not, to evade apprehension.

qas.question: What does 'harbour' include in this Sanhita?

answers.text: Supplying a person with shelter, food, drink, money, clothes, arms, ammunition or means of conveyance, or the assisting a person by any means, whether of the same kind as those enumerated in this clause or not, to evade apprehension.

paragraphs.context: Injury means any harm whatever illegally caused to any person, in body, mind, reputation or property. Illegal is applicable to everything which is an offence or which is prohibited by law, or which furnishes ground for a civil action.

paragraphs.context: Judge means a person who is officially designated as a Judge and includes a person empowered by law to give, in any legal proceeding, civil or criminal, a definitive judgment, or a judgment which, if not appealed against, would be definitive.
