data.title: Offences by or Relating to Public Servants

paragraphs.context: Whoever, being a public servant, knowingly disobeys any direction of the law as to the way in which he is to conduct himself as such public servant, intending to cause, or knowing it to be likely that he will by such disobedience, cause injury to any person, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for knowingly disobeying the law as a public servant?

answers.text: Simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, being a public servant,— (a) knowingly disobeys any direction of the law which prohibits him from requiring the attendance at any place of any person for the purpose of investigation into an offence or any other matter; or (b) knowingly disobeys, to the prejudice of any person, any other direction of the law regulating the manner in which he shall conduct such investigation; or (c) fails to record any information given to him under sub-section (1) of section 173 of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023 in relation to cognizable offence punishable under various sections, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than six months but which may extend to two years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for failing to record information under Section 173?

answers.text: Rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than six months but which may extend to two years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, being in charge of a hospital, public or private, whether run by the Central Government, the State Government, local bodies or any other person, contravenes the provisions of section 397 of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023, shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for contravening Section 397 as a hospital in-charge?

answers.text: Imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, being a public servant, and being, as such public servant, charged with the preparation or translation of any document or electronic record, frames, prepares or translates that document or electronic record in a manner which he knows or believes to be incorrect, intending thereby to cause or knowing it to be likely that he may thereby cause injury to any person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for preparing incorrect documents as a public servant?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever pretends to hold any particular office as a public servant, knowing that he does not hold such office or falsely personates any other person holding such office, and in such assumed character does or attempts to do any act under colour of such office, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than six months but which may extend to three years and with fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for falsely personating a public servant?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than six months but which may extend to three years and with fine.

data.title: Indian Penal Code - Illustrations and Exceptions

paragraphs.context: Illustrations. (a) A, under the influence of passion excited by a provocation given by Z, intentionally kills Y, Z’s child. This is murder, in as much as the provocation was not given by the child, and the death of the child was not caused by accident or misfortune in doing an act caused by the provocation.

qas.question: Why is A's act considered murder in Illustration (a)?

answers.text: the provocation was not given by the child, and the death of the child was not caused by accident or misfortune in doing an act caused by the provocation

paragraphs.context: (b) Y gives grave and sudden provocation to A. A, on this provocation, fires a pistol at Y, neither intending nor knowing himself to be likely to kill Z, who is near him, but out of sight. A kills Z. Here A has not committed murder, but merely culpable homicide.

qas.question: What offense does A commit in Illustration (b)?

answers.text: culpable homicide

paragraphs.context: (c) A is lawfully arrested by Z, a bailiff. A is excited to sudden and violent passion by the arrest, and kills Z. This is murder, in as much as the provocation was given by a thing done by a public servant in the exercise of his powers.

qas.question: Why is A's act in Illustration (c) considered murder?

answers.text: the provocation was given by a thing done by a public servant in the exercise of his powers

paragraphs.context: (d) A appears as a witness before Z, a Magistrate. Z says that he does not believe a word of A’s deposition, and that A has perjured himself. A is moved to sudden passion by these words, and kills Z. This is murder.

qas.question: What provoked A to commit murder in Illustration (d)?

answers.text: Z says that he does not believe a word of A’s deposition, and that A has perjured himself

paragraphs.context: (e) A attempts to pull Z’s nose. Z, in the exercise of the right of private defence, lays hold of A to prevent him from doing so. A is moved to sudden and violent passion in consequence, and kills Z. This is murder, in as much as the provocation was giving by a thing done in the exercise of the right of private defence.

qas.question: Why is A's act in Illustration (e) considered murder?

answers.text: the provocation was giving by a thing done in the exercise of the right of private defence

paragraphs.context: (f) Z strikes B. B is by this provocation excited to violent rage. A, a bystander, intending to take advantage of B’s rage, and to cause him to kill Z, puts a knife into B’s hand for that purpose. B kills Z. Here B may have committed only culpable homicide, but A is guilty of murder.

qas.question: Why is A guilty of murder in Illustration (f)?

answers.text: A, a bystander, intending to take advantage of B’s rage, and to cause him to kill Z, puts a knife into B’s hand for that purpose

paragraphs.context: Exception 2.—Culpable homicide is not murder if the offender in the exercise in good faith of the right of private defence of person or property, exceeds the power given to him by law and causes the death of the person against whom he is exercising such right of defence without premeditation, and without any intention of doing more harm than is necessary for the purpose of such defence.

qas.question: Under what condition does Exception 2 apply to culpable homicide?

answers.text: if the offender in the exercise in good faith of the right of private defence of person or property, exceeds the power given to him by law and causes the death of the person against whom he is exercising such right of defence without premeditation, and without any intention of doing more harm than is necessary for the purpose of such defence

paragraphs.context: Exception 3.—Culpable homicide is not murder if the offender, being a public servant or aiding a public servant acting for the advancement of public justice, exceeds the powers given to him by law, and causes death by doing an act which he, in good faith, believes to be lawful and necessary for the due discharge of his duty as such public servant and without ill-will towards the person whose death is caused.

qas.question: When does Exception 3 apply to culpable homicide?

answers.text: if the offender, being a public servant or aiding a public servant acting for the advancement of public justice, exceeds the powers given to him by law, and causes death by doing an act which he, in good faith, believes to be lawful and necessary for the due discharge of his duty as such public servant and without ill-will towards the person whose death is caused

paragraphs.context: Exception 4.—Culpable homicide is not murder if it is committed without premeditation in a sudden fight in the heat of passion upon a sudden quarrel and without the offender’s having taken undue advantage or acted in a cruel or unusual manner. Explanation.—It is immaterial in such cases which party offers the provocation or commits the first assault.

qas.question: What conditions must be met for Exception 4 to apply to culpable homicide?

answers.text: if it is committed without premeditation in a sudden fight in the heat of passion upon a sudden quarrel and without the offender’s having taken undue advantage or acted in a cruel or unusual manner

paragraphs.context: Exception 5.—Culpable homicide is not murder when the person whose death is caused, being above the age of eighteen years, suffers death or takes the risk of death with his own consent.

qas.question: When does Exception 5 apply to culpable homicide?

answers.text: when the person whose death is caused, being above the age of eighteen years, suffers death or takes the risk of death with his own consent

paragraphs.context: Illustration. A, by instigation, voluntarily causes Z, a child to commit suicide. Here, on account of Z’s youth, he was incapable of giving consent to his own death; A has therefore abetted murder.

qas.question: Why is A guilty of abetting murder in the Exception 5 illustration?

answers.text: on account of Z’s youth, he was incapable of giving consent to his own death

paragraphs.context: (22) “number”.—Unless the contrary appears from the context, words importing the singular number include the plural number, and words importing the plural number include the singular number.

answers.text: Words importing the singular number include the plural number, and words importing the plural number include the singular number.

paragraphs.context: (23) “oath” includes a solemn affirmation substituted by law for an oath, and any declaration required or authorised by law to be made before a public servant or to be used for the purpose of proof, whether in a Court or not.

answers.text: A solemn affirmation substituted by law for an oath, and any declaration required or authorised by law to be made before a public servant or to be used for the purpose of proof, whether in a Court or not.

paragraphs.context: (24) “offence”.—Except in the Chapters and sections mentioned in sub-clauses (a) and (b), the word “offence” means a thing made punishable by this Sanhita, but–– (a) in Chapter III and in the following sections, namely, sub-sections (2), (3), (4) and (5) of section 8, sections 9, 49, 50, 52, 54, 55, 56, 57, 58, 59, 60, 61, 119, 120, 123, sub-sections (7) and (8) of section 127, 222, 230, 231, 240, 248, 250, 251, 259, 260, 261, 262, 263, sub-sections (6) and (7) of section 308 and sub-section (2) of section 330, the word “offence” means a thing punishable under this Sanhita, or under any special law or local law; and (b) in sub-section (1) of section 189, sections 211, 212, 238, 239, 249, 253 and sub-section (1) of section 329, the word “offence” shall have the same meaning when the act punishable under the special law or local law is punishable under such law with imprisonment for a term of six months or more, whether with or without fine.

qas.question: What is the general definition of 'offence' in this Sanhita?

answers.text: A thing made punishable by this Sanhita.

qas.question: What is the meaning of 'offence' in Chapter III and certain sections of the Sanhita?

answers.text: A thing punishable under this Sanhita, or under any special law or local law.

qas.question: What is the meaning of 'offence' in sections such as 211, 212, and 329?

answers.text: The act punishable under the special law or local law is punishable under such law with imprisonment for a term of six months or more, whether with or without fine.

paragraphs.context: (25) “omission” denotes as well a series of omissions as a single omission.

qas.question: How is 'omission' defined in this Sanhita?

answers.text: A series of omissions as well as a single omission.

paragraphs.context: (26) “person” includes any company or association or body of persons, whether incorporated or not.

qas.question: What does the term 'person' include in this Sanhita?

answers.text: Any company or association or body of persons, whether incorporated or not.

paragraphs.context: (27) “public” includes any class of the public or any community.

qas.question: What is the definition of 'public' in this Sanhita?

answers.text: Any class of the public or any community.

paragraphs.context: (28) “public servant” means a person falling under any of the descriptions, namely: (a) every commissioned officer in the Army, Navy or Air Force; (b) every Judge including any person empowered by law to discharge, whether by himself or as a member of any body of persons, any adjudicatory functions...

answers.text: A person falling under any of the descriptions, namely: (a) every commissioned officer in the Army, Navy or Air Force...

data.title: Indian Penal Code - Attempt to Commit Culpable Homicide and Organised Crime

paragraphs.context: (2) When any person offending under sub-section (1) is under sentence of imprisonment for life, he may, if hurt is caused, be punished with death or with imprisonment for life, which shall mean the remainder of that person’s natural life.

qas.question: What happens if a person, already under sentence of imprisonment for life, offends under sub-section (1) and causes hurt?

answers.text: he may, if hurt is caused, be punished with death or with imprisonment for life, which shall mean the remainder of that person’s natural life

paragraphs.context: Illustrations. (a) A shoots at Z with intention to kill him, under such circumstances that, if death ensued, A would be guilty of murder. A is liable to punishment under this section. (b) A, with the intention of causing the death of a child of tender years, exposes it in a desert place. A has committed the offence defined by this section, though the death of the child does not ensue. (c) A, intending to murder Z, buys a gun and loads it. A has not yet committed the offence. A fires the gun at Z. He has committed the offence defined in this section, and, if by such firing he wounds Z, he is liable to the punishment provided by the latter part of sub-section (1). (d) A, intending to murder Z by poison, purchases poison and mixes the same with food which remains in A’s keeping; A has not yet committed the offence defined in this section. A places the food on Z’s table or delivers it to Z’s servants to place it on Z’s table. A has committed the offence defined in this section.

qas.question: What happens in illustration (a) when A shoots at Z with the intention to kill him?

answers.text: A is liable to punishment under this section

qas.question: In illustration (b), what does A do with the intention of causing the death of a child?

answers.text: A exposes it in a desert place

qas.question: What happens when A, intending to murder Z, buys a gun and loads it in illustration (c)?

answers.text: A has not yet committed the offence

qas.question: What happens when A, intending to murder Z by poison, purchases poison and places it on Z’s table in illustration (d)?

answers.text: A has committed the offence defined in this section

paragraphs.context: 110. Whoever does any act with such intention or knowledge and under such circumstances that, if he by that act caused death, he would be guilty of culpable homicide not amounting to murder, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both; and, if hurt is caused to any person by such act, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for committing an act with intention or knowledge that would cause culpable homicide not amounting to murder under Section 110?

answers.text: punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both

qas.question: What happens if hurt is caused to any person by an act under Section 110?

answers.text: punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both

paragraphs.context: Attempt to commit culpable homicide. Illustration. A, on grave and sudden provocation, fires a pistol at Z, under such circumstances that if he thereby caused death, he would be guilty of culpable homicide not amounting to murder. A has committed the offence defined in this section.

qas.question: What does A do in the illustration related to attempt to commit culpable homicide?

answers.text: fires a pistol at Z, under such circumstances that if he thereby caused death, he would be guilty of culpable homicide not amounting to murder

paragraphs.context: 111. (1) Any continuing unlawful activity including kidnapping, robbery, vehicle theft, extortion, land grabbing, contract killing, economic offence, cyber-crimes, trafficking of persons, drugs, weapons or illicit goods or services, human trafficking for prostitution or ransom, by any person or a group of persons acting in concert, singly or jointly, either as a member of an organised crime syndicate or on behalf of such syndicate, by use of violence, threat of violence, intimidation, coercion, or by any other unlawful means to obtain direct or indirect material benefit including a financial benefit, shall constitute organised crime. Explanation.—For the purposes of this sub-section,–– (i) “organised crime syndicate” means a group of two or more persons who, acting either singly or jointly, as a syndicate or gang indulge in any continuing unlawful activity; (ii) “continuing unlawful activity” means an activity prohibited by law which is a cognizable offence punishable with imprisonment of three years or more, undertaken by any person, either singly or jointly, as a member of an organised crime syndicate.

qas.question: What constitutes organised crime under Section 111(1)?

answers.text: Any continuing unlawful activity including kidnapping, robbery, vehicle theft, extortion, land grabbing, contract killing, economic offence, cyber-crimes, trafficking of persons, drugs, weapons or illicit goods or services, human trafficking for prostitution or ransom

qas.question: What is the definition of an organised crime syndicate under Section 111?

answers.text: a group of two or more persons who, acting either singly or jointly, as a syndicate or gang indulge in any continuing unlawful activity

paragraphs.context: Punishments for Mischief: General Misdeed: Whoever commits mischief shall be punished with imprisonment up to 6 months, a fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for general mischief?

answers.text: The punishment for general mischief is imprisonment up to 6 months, a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: Definition of Mischief: Mischief occurs when someone, with intent to cause or knowing they are likely to cause wrongful loss or damage to the public or any person, causes the destruction of property, alters property in a way that diminishes its value, or harms its utility.

qas.question: What is the definition of mischief?

answers.text: Mischief occurs when someone, with intent to cause or knowing they are likely to cause wrongful loss or damage to the public or any person, causes the destruction of property, alters property in a way that diminishes its value, or harms its utility.

paragraphs.context: Stolen Property Definition: Property obtained through theft, extortion, robbery, cheating, or criminal breach of trust is considered 'stolen property' whether the act occurred in India or elsewhere. If the stolen property comes into the possession of someone legally entitled to it, it is no longer considered stolen.

qas.question: What defines stolen property under Section 317?

answers.text: Stolen property is property obtained through theft, extortion, robbery, cheating, or criminal breach of trust, whether the act occurred in India or elsewhere. If legally entitled, it is no longer considered stolen.

paragraphs.context: Punishment for Receiving Stolen Property: If someone dishonestly receives or retains stolen property, knowing or having reason to believe it is stolen, they can be punished with imprisonment for up to 3 years, a fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for receiving stolen property under Section 317?

answers.text: The punishment for receiving stolen property under Section 317 is imprisonment for up to 3 years, a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: Punishment for Receiving Stolen Property from Dacoits or Habitually: Receiving from a Dacoit: If someone dishonestly receives stolen property from a person whom they know or have reason to believe is part of a gang of dacoits, and they know or believe the property to be stolen, they can be punished with life imprisonment or rigorous imprisonment for up to 10 years, along with a fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for receiving stolen property from dacoits?

answers.text: The punishment for receiving stolen property from a dacoit is life imprisonment or rigorous imprisonment for up to 10 years, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: Habitual Dealing in Stolen Property: Anyone who habitually receives or deals in property they know or believe to be stolen can be punished with life imprisonment or imprisonment for up to 10 years, along with a fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for habitual dealing in stolen property?

answers.text: The punishment for habitual dealing in stolen property is life imprisonment or imprisonment for up to 10 years, along with a fine.

paragraphs.context: Concealing or Disposing of Stolen Property: Anyone who voluntarily helps conceal, dispose of, or make away with stolen property, knowing or believing it to be stolen, can be punished with up to 3 years imprisonment, a fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for concealing or disposing of stolen property?

answers.text: The punishment for concealing or disposing of stolen property is up to 3 years imprisonment, a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: Mischief by Fire or Explosives: If the mischief involves fire or explosives, the punishment increases: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment for up to 10 years, and a fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for mischief involving fire or explosives on transport infrastructure?

answers.text: The punishment for mischief involving fire or explosives on transport infrastructure is imprisonment for life, or imprisonment for up to 10 years, and a fine.

paragraphs.context: A gives his watch to Z, a jeweler, for regulation. Z takes it to his shop. A, without owing Z any debt, forcibly takes it back. A may commit trespass or assault but not theft.

qas.question: Why does A not commit theft when forcibly taking back his watch from Z’s shop without a debt?

answers.text: Because A does not owe Z any debt, forcibly taking back the watch may be trespass or assault but not theft.

paragraphs.context: If A owes Z for watch repairs and Z lawfully retains it as security, A commits theft if he takes it back dishonestly, depriving Z of his security.

qas.question: Under what condition does A commit theft when taking back his watch that Z lawfully retains as security for repairs?

answers.text: A commits theft if he takes it back dishonestly, depriving Z of his security.

paragraphs.context: If A pawns his watch to Z and reclaims it without Z’s consent or repaying the loan, he commits theft, even though the watch is his.

qas.question: Why does A commit theft when reclaiming his pawned watch without Z’s consent or repaying the loan?

answers.text: Because A reclaims the watch dishonestly without Z’s consent or repaying the loan, constituting theft.

paragraphs.context: Section 315: Anyone who dishonestly takes or uses property that belonged to someone who has passed away, knowing it was in their possession at the time of their death and has not yet been claimed by someone legally entitled to it, can be punished with imprisonment for up to three years and may also be fined. If the person was employed by the deceased (as a clerk or servant), the punishment can extend to seven years.

qas.question: What is the punishment for dishonestly taking or using property belonging to a deceased person?

answers.text: The punishment for dishonestly taking or using property belonging to a deceased person is imprisonment for up to three years, or a fine. If the person was employed by the deceased, the punishment can extend to seven years.

paragraphs.context: Example: Z dies leaving behind furniture and money. His servant A takes the money before it is legally handed over to the rightful person. A is guilty under this section.

qas.question: Give an example of someone being guilty under Section 315.

answers.text: An example of someone being guilty under Section 315 is when A, the servant of a deceased person, takes money before it is legally handed over to the rightful person.

paragraphs.context: Section 316: If someone is entrusted with property or authority over property and dishonestly uses or takes that property for themselves, or fails to follow legal or contractual instructions on how to handle it, they commit criminal breach of trust. If they allow someone else to do this, they are also guilty.

qas.question: What constitutes criminal breach of trust under Section 316?

answers.text: Criminal breach of trust occurs when someone entrusted with property or authority over property dishonestly uses or takes the property for themselves or fails to follow legal or contractual instructions on handling it.

paragraphs.context: Examples: If an employer deducts the employee's contribution for a Provident Fund but does not deposit it into the Fund, they have misused that money, which is a breach of trust. If an employer deducts the employee's contribution for the Employees' State Insurance Fund but doesn’t transfer it to the Fund, they are also guilty of criminal breach of trust.

qas.question: What are examples of criminal breach of trust under Section 316?

answers.text: Examples of criminal breach of trust under Section 316 include an employer misusing the Provident Fund or Employees' State Insurance Fund contributions by failing to deposit them as required.

paragraphs.context: Illustration: (a) A is an executor of a will and is supposed to distribute the deceased person's belongings according to the will. If A takes the property for themselves instead of following the will, A is guilty of criminal breach of trust.

qas.question: What is an illustration of criminal breach of trust?

answers.text: An illustration of criminal breach of trust is when A, as an executor of a will, takes the property for themselves instead of distributing it according to the will.

paragraphs.context: In summary, if you are given responsibility over property or funds and misuse or fail to follow the rules for handling them, you are committing criminal breach of trust.

qas.question: What is the summary of Section 316 on criminal breach of trust?

answers.text: The summary of Section 316 is that if you are entrusted with property or funds and misuse or fail to follow instructions on handling them, you commit criminal breach of trust.

paragraphs.context: Theft is snatching if, in order to commit theft, the offender suddenly or quickly or forcibly seizes or secures or grabs or takes away from any person or from his possession any movable property.

qas.question: What defines theft as snatching?

answers.text: Theft is snatching when the offender suddenly, quickly, or forcibly takes away property from a person or their possession.

paragraphs.context: Whoever commits snatching, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for committing snatching?

answers.text: The punishment for snatching is imprisonment for up to three years and a fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever commits theft— (a) in any building, tent or vessel used as a human dwelling or used for the custody of property; or (b) of any means of transport used for the transport of goods or passengers; or (c) of any article or goods from any means of transport used for the transport of goods or passengers; or (d) of idol or icon in any place of worship; or (e) of any property of the Government or of a local authority, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What are the punishments for theft in specific circumstances?

answers.text: The punishment for theft in specific circumstances is imprisonment for up to seven years and a fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, being a clerk or servant, or being employed in the capacity of a clerk or servant, commits theft in respect of any property in the possession of his master or employer, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for a clerk or servant committing theft?

answers.text: A clerk or servant committing theft in the possession of their employer will be punished with imprisonment for up to seven years and a fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever commits theft, having made preparation for causing death, or hurt, or restraint, or fear of death, or of hurt, or of restraint, to any person, in order to the committing of such theft, or in order to the effecting of his escape after the committing of such theft, or in order to the retaining of property taken by such theft, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for theft involving preparation for death, hurt, or restraint?

answers.text: The punishment is rigorous imprisonment for up to ten years and a fine.

paragraphs.context: Illustrations. (a) A commits theft on property in Z’s possession; and while committing this theft, he has a loaded pistol under his garment, having provided this pistol for the purpose of hurting Z in case Z should resist. A has committed the offence defined in this section. (b) A picks Z’s pocket, having posted several of his companions near him, in order that they may restrain Z, if Z should perceive what is passing and should resist, or should attempt to apprehend A. A has committed the offence defined in this section.

qas.question: What is illustrated in these examples?

answers.text: These examples illustrate that when theft is committed with preparation to cause harm or restraint, it is considered a more severe offence.

paragraphs.context:
Section 358: Repeal and Savings of the Indian Penal Code
Repeal of the Indian Penal Code: The Indian Penal Code (IPC) is officially repealed under this section.
Exceptions to Repeal: Despite the repeal, the following provisions are unaffected: a. Previous Operations: The previous operation of the repealed Code or anything that was lawfully done or suffered under it remains valid. b. Rights and Liabilities: Any rights, privileges, obligations, or liabilities acquired under the repealed Code are still valid. c. Penalties and Punishments: Any penalties or punishments incurred for offenses committed under the repealed Code continue to apply. d. Investigations: Investigations or remedies related to any penalties or punishments incurred remain valid. e. Proceedings: Proceedings, investigations, or remedies related to penalties or punishments incurred may be continued, and penalties can still be imposed as if the Code had not been repealed.

qas.question: What does Section 358 of the Indian Penal Code deal with?

answers.text: The repeal of the Indian Penal Code and the exceptions to the repeal.

paragraphs.context: Actions Under the Repealed Code: Anything done or any action taken under the repealed Indian Penal Code shall be treated as if it was done under the corresponding provisions of the new Code (Sanhita). General Clauses Act, 1897: The repeal of the Indian Penal Code does not affect the general application of Section 6 of the General Clauses Act, 1897, which governs the effects of repeal.

qas.question: What happens to actions done under the repealed Indian Penal Code?

answers.text: Anything done or any action taken under the repealed Indian Penal Code shall be treated as if it was done under the corresponding provisions of the new Code (Sanhita).

data.title: Indian Penal Code - Explanation on Homicide and Murder

paragraphs.context: Explanation 2.—Where death is caused by bodily injury, the person who causes such bodily injury shall be deemed to have caused the death, although by resorting to proper remedies and skilful treatment the death might have been prevented.

qas.question: Who is deemed to have caused death in the case of bodily injury?

answers.text: the person who causes such bodily injury

qas.question: Can death by bodily injury still be considered caused if it could have been prevented by treatment?

answers.text: Yes

paragraphs.context: Explanation 3.—The causing of the death of a child in the mother’s womb is not homicide. But it may amount to culpable homicide to cause the death of a living child, if any part of that child has been brought forth, though the child may not have breathed or been completely born.

qas.question: Is causing the death of a child in the mother’s womb considered homicide?

answers.text: No

qas.question: Under what condition can the death of a living child be considered culpable homicide?

answers.text: if any part of that child has been brought forth

paragraphs.context: 101. Except in the cases hereinafter excepted, culpable homicide is murder,–– (a) if the act by which the death is caused is done with the intention of causing death; or (b) if the act by which the death is caused is done with the intention of causing such bodily injury as the offender knows to be likely to cause the death of the person to whom the harm is caused; or (c) if the act by which the death is caused is done with the intention of causing bodily injury to any person and the bodily injury intended to be inflicted is sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death; or (d) if the person committing the act by which the death is caused, knows that it is so imminently dangerous that it must, in all probability, cause death, or such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, and commits such act without any excuse for incurring the risk of causing death or such injury as aforesaid.

qas.question: What are the conditions under which culpable homicide is considered murder?

answers.text: (a) if the act by which the death is caused is done with the intention of causing death; or (b) if the act by which the death is caused is done with the intention of causing such bodily injury as the offender knows to be likely to cause the death of the person to whom the harm is caused; or (c) if the act by which the death is caused is done with the intention of causing bodily injury to any person and the bodily injury intended to be inflicted is sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death; or (d) if the person committing the act by which the death is caused, knows that it is so imminently dangerous that it must, in all probability, cause death, or such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, and commits such act without any excuse for incurring the risk of causing death or such injury as aforesaid.

qas.question: What must a person know about their act for it to be considered murder under condition (d)?

answers.text: that it is so imminently dangerous that it must, in all probability, cause death, or such bodily injury as is likely to cause death

paragraphs.context: Exception 1.—Culpable homicide is not murder if the offender, whilst deprived of the power of self-control by grave and sudden provocation, causes the death of the person who gave the provocation or causes the death of any other person by mistake or accident: Provided that the provocation is not,–– (a) sought or voluntarily provoked by the offender as an excuse for killing or doing harm to any person; (b) given by anything done in obedience to the law, or by a public servant in the lawful exercise of the powers of such public servant; (c) given by anything done in the lawful exercise of the right of private defence.

qas.question: What is the exception for culpable homicide not being considered murder?

answers.text: if the offender, whilst deprived of the power of self-control by grave and sudden provocation, causes the death of the person who gave the provocation or causes the death of any other person by mistake or accident

qas.question: What conditions prevent provocation from being considered valid for this exception?

answers.text: (a) sought or voluntarily provoked by the offender as an excuse for killing or doing harm to any person; (b) given by anything done in obedience to the law, or by a public servant in the lawful exercise of the powers of such public servant; (c) given by anything done in the lawful exercise of the right of private defence.

data.title: Offences Relating to Evidence and Information

paragraphs.context: Whoever corruptly uses or attempts to use as true or genuine evidence any evidence which he knows to be false or fabricated, shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave or fabricated false evidence.

qas.question: What is the punishment for using or attempting to use false evidence?

answers.text: Punished in the same manner as if he gave or fabricated false evidence.

paragraphs.context: Whoever issues or signs any certificate required by law to be given or signed, or relating to any fact of which such certificate is by law admissible in evidence, knowing or believing that such certificate is false in any material point, shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.

qas.question: What is the punishment for issuing or signing a false certificate?

answers.text: Punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.

paragraphs.context: Whoever corruptly uses or attempts to use any such certificate as a true certificate, knowing the same to be false in any material point, shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.

qas.question: What is the punishment for using or attempting to use a false certificate as true?

answers.text: Punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, in any declaration made or subscribed by him, which declaration any Court or any public servant or other person, is bound or authorised by law to receive as evidence of any fact, makes any statement which is false, and which he either knows or believes to be false or does not believe to be true, touching any point material to the object for which the declaration is made or used, shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.

qas.question: What is the punishment for making a false statement in a declaration?

answers.text: Punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.

paragraphs.context: Whoever corruptly uses or attempts to use as true any such declaration, knowing the same to be false in any material point, shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.

qas.question: What is the punishment for using a false declaration as true?

answers.text: Punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, knowing or having reason to believe that an offence has been committed, causes any evidence of the commission of that offence to disappear, with the intention of screening the offender from legal punishment, or with that intention gives any information respecting the offence which he knows or believes to be false shall,— (a) if the offence which he knows or believes to have been committed is punishable with death, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine; (b) if the offence is punishable with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment which may extend to ten years, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine; (c) if the offence is punishable with imprisonment for any term not extending to ten years, be punished with imprisonment of the description provided for the offence, for a term which may extend to one-fourth part of the longest term of the imprisonment provided for the offence, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for causing evidence to disappear in case of an offence punishable with death?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, knowing or having reason to believe that an offence has been committed, causes any evidence of the commission of that offence to disappear, with the intention of screening the offender from legal punishment, or with that intention gives any information respecting the offence which he knows or believes to be false shall,— (a) if the offence which he knows or believes to have been committed is punishable with death, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine; (b) if the offence is punishable with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment which may extend to ten years, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine; (c) if the offence is punishable with imprisonment for any term not extending to ten years, be punished with imprisonment of the description provided for the offence, for a term which may extend to one-fourth part of the longest term of the imprisonment provided for the offence, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for causing evidence to disappear in case of an offence punishable with imprisonment for life?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for causing evidence to disappear for an offence punishable with imprisonment for a term not extending to ten years?

answers.text: Imprisonment of the description provided for the offence, for a term which may extend to one-fourth part of the longest term of the imprisonment provided for the offence, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, knowing or having reason to believe that an offence has been committed, intentionally omits to give any information respecting that offence which he is legally bound to give, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for intentionally omitting to give information about an offence?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.

data.title: Offences Relating to Obscenity and Religion

paragraphs.context: Whoever sells, lets to hire, distributes, exhibits or circulates to any child any such obscene object as is referred to in section 294, or offers or attempts so to do, shall be punished on first conviction with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and with fine which may extend to two thousand rupees, and, in the event of a second or subsequent conviction, with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and also with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees.

qas.question: What is the punishment for the first conviction under Section 295?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and with fine which may extend to two thousand rupees.

qas.question: What is the punishment for subsequent convictions under Section 295?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and also with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, to the annoyance of others,— (a) does any obscene act in any public place; or (b) sings, recites or utters any obscene song, ballad or words, in or near any public place, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for committing an obscene act in public under Section 296?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever keeps any office or place for the purpose of drawing any lottery not being a State lottery or a lottery authorised by the State Government, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both. Whoever publishes any proposal to pay any sum, or to deliver any goods, or to do or forbear from doing anything for the benefit of any person, on any event or contingency relative or applicable to the drawing of any ticket, lot, number or figure in any such lottery, shall be punished with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees.

qas.question: What is the punishment for keeping an office for unauthorized lotteries under Section 297?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for publishing proposals related to unauthorized lotteries?

answers.text: Fine which may extend to five thousand rupees.

paragraphs.context: Whoever destroys, damages or defiles any place of worship, or any object held sacred by any class of persons with the intention of thereby insulting the religion of any class of persons or with the knowledge that any class of persons is likely to consider such destruction, damage or defilement as an insult to their religion, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for insulting religion by damaging sacred objects under Section 298?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, with deliberate and malicious intention of outraging the religious feelings of any class of citizens of India, by words, either spoken or written, or by signs or by visible representations or through electronic means or otherwise, insults or attempts to insult the religion or the religious beliefs of that class, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for outraging religious feelings under Section 299?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever voluntarily causes disturbance to any assembly lawfully engaged in the performance of religious worship, or religious ceremonies, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for disturbing a religious assembly under Section 300?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

paragraphs.context: Mischief Leading to Loss/Damage Over ₹1 Lakh: If mischief causes loss or damage to the amount of ₹1 lakh or more, the punishment is imprisonment up to 5 years, a fine, or both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for mischief leading to loss or damage over ₹1 Lakh?

answers.text: The punishment for mischief leading to loss or damage over ₹1 Lakh is imprisonment up to 5 years, a fine, or both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever, intending to facilitate or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby facilitate the commission of an offence punishable with imprisonment, voluntarily conceals, by any act or illegal omission, the existence of a design to commit such offence, or makes any representation which he knows to be false respecting such design shall,–– (a) if the offence be committed, be punished with imprisonment of the description provided for the offence, for a term which may extend to one-fourth; and (b) if the offence be not committed, to one-eighth, of the longest term of such imprisonment, or with such fine as is provided for the offence, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for concealing a design to commit an offence if the offence is committed?

answers.text: Imprisonment of the description provided for the offence, for a term which may extend to one-fourth of the longest term of such imprisonment, or with such fine as is provided for the offence, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for concealing a design to commit an offence if the offence is not committed?

answers.text: Imprisonment of the description provided for the offence, for a term which may extend to one-eighth of the longest term of such imprisonment, or with such fine as is provided for the offence, or with both.

paragraphs.context: When two or more persons agree with the common object to do, or cause to be done–– (a) an illegal act; or (b) an act which is not illegal by illegal means, such an agreement is designated a criminal conspiracy: Provided that no agreement except an agreement to commit an offence shall amount to a criminal conspiracy unless some act besides the agreement is done by one or more parties to such agreement in pursuance thereof. Explanation.—It is immaterial whether the illegal act is the ultimate object of such agreement, or is merely incidental to that object.

qas.question: What constitutes a criminal conspiracy?

answers.text: An agreement between two or more persons to do an illegal act or an act which is not illegal by illegal means.

qas.question: Does a criminal conspiracy require an act besides the agreement?

answers.text: Yes, no agreement except an agreement to commit an offence shall amount to a criminal conspiracy unless some act besides the agreement is done by one or more parties to such agreement in pursuance thereof.

qas.question: Is it necessary for the illegal act to be the ultimate object of the agreement in a criminal conspiracy?

answers.text: No, it is immaterial whether the illegal act is the ultimate object of such agreement, or is merely incidental to that object.

paragraphs.context: Whoever is a party to a criminal conspiracy,–– (a) to commit an offence punishable with death, imprisonment for life or rigorous imprisonment for a term of two years or upwards, shall, where no express provision is made in this Sanhita for the punishment of such a conspiracy, be punished in the same manner as if he had abetted such offence; (b) other than a criminal conspiracy to commit an offence punishable as aforesaid shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term not exceeding six months, or with fine or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for a criminal conspiracy to commit an offence punishable with death, life imprisonment, or rigorous imprisonment for two years or more?

answers.text: Punished in the same manner as if he had abetted such offence.

qas.question: What is the punishment for a criminal conspiracy to commit an offence not punishable with death, life imprisonment, or rigorous imprisonment for two years or more?

answers.text: Imprisonment of either description for a term not exceeding six months, or with fine or with both.

paragraphs.context: Whoever attempts to commit an offence punishable by this Sanhita with imprisonment for life or imprisonment, or to cause such an offence to be committed, and in such attempt does any act towards the commission of the offence, shall, where no express provision is made by this Sanhita for the punishment of such attempt, be punished with imprisonment of any description provided for the offence, for a term which may extend to one-half of the imprisonment for life or, as the case may be, one-half of the longest term of imprisonment provided for that offence, or with such fine as is provided for the offence, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for an attempt to commit an offence punishable with life imprisonment or imprisonment, where no express provision is made?

answers.text: Imprisonment of any description provided for the offence, for a term which may extend to one-half of the imprisonment for life or, as the case may be, one-half of the longest term of imprisonment provided for that offence, or with such fine as is provided for the offence, or with both.

paragraphs.context: A makes an attempt to steal some jewels by breaking open a box, and finds after so opening the box, that there is no jewel in it. He has done an act towards the commission of theft, and therefore is guilty under this section.

qas.question: What happens if a person attempts to steal jewels by breaking open a box but finds no jewels?

answers.text: He has done an act towards the commission of theft, and therefore is guilty under this section.

paragraphs.context: A makes an attempt to pick the pocket of Z by thrusting his hand into Z’s pocket. A fails in the attempt in consequence of Z’s having nothing in his pocket. A is guilty under this section.

qas.question: Is a person guilty of attempting to pick a pocket if the pocket is empty?

answers.text: Yes, A is guilty under this section.

paragraphs.context: Definition of Cheating by Personation: A person cheats by pretending to be someone else or by substituting one person for another, representing that they or another person is someone other than they truly are. This offense can occur whether the person being impersonated is real or imaginary.

qas.question: What is cheating by personation?

answers.text: Cheating by personation occurs when a person pretends to be someone else or substitutes one person for another, representing themselves or another person as someone other than they truly are.

data.title: Offences Related to Public Harmony and Sovereignty

paragraphs.context: Whoever by words, either spoken or written, or by signs or by visible representations or through electronic communication or otherwise, promotes or attempts to promote, on grounds of religion, race, place of birth, residence, language, caste or community or any other ground whatsoever, disharmony or feelings of enmity, hatred or ill-will between different religious, racial, language or regional groups or castes or communities shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for promoting disharmony between different groups?

answers.text: Imprisonment which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What actions can lead to punishment under this law?

answers.text: Promotes or attempts to promote, on grounds of religion, race, place of birth, residence, language, caste or community or any other ground whatsoever, disharmony or feelings of enmity, hatred or ill-will between different groups.

paragraphs.context: Whoever commits an offence specified in sub-section (1) in any place of worship or in any assembly engaged in the performance of religious worship or religious ceremonies, shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to five years and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the punishment for committing the offence in a place of worship?

answers.text: Imprisonment which may extend to five years and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Whoever by words either spoken or written or by signs or by visible representations or through electronic communication or otherwise, makes or publishes any imputation that any class of persons cannot, by reason of their being members of any religious, racial, language or regional group or caste or community, bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of India as by law established or uphold the sovereignty and integrity of India shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What is the punishment for making imputations against a class of persons regarding their faith in the Constitution?

answers.text: Imprisonment which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

qas.question: What kind of imputations are punishable under this law?

answers.text: Imputations that any class of persons cannot, by reason of their being members of any religious, racial, language or regional group or caste or community, bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of India or uphold the sovereignty and integrity of India.

paragraphs.context: Whoever commits an offence specified in sub-section (1) in any place of worship or in any assembly engaged in the performance of religious worship or religious ceremonies, shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to five years and shall also be liable to fine.

qas.question: What is the enhanced punishment for committing an offence in a religious assembly?

answers.text: Imprisonment which may extend to five years and shall also be liable to fine.

paragraphs.context: Illustrations: Example 1: A burns a valuable security belonging to Z, intending to cause loss to Z. This is mischief. Example 2: A introduces water into an ice-house owned by Z, causing the ice to melt, with the intent to cause damage to Z. This is mischief.

qas.question: Give examples of mischief.

answers.text: Example 1: A burns a valuable security belonging to Z, intending to cause loss to Z. Example 2: A introduces water into an ice-house owned by Z, causing the ice to melt, with the intent to cause damage to Z.
